2. The applicants' allegations

The applicants allege that the Russian authorities failed to take adequate measures to investigate their relatives' disappearance, in particular by not conducting a thorough investigation into the circumstances surrounding their detention and subsequent disappearance. They also allege that the Russian authorities failed to provide them with any information about the fate or whereabouts of their relatives.

3. The investigation

The investigation into the disappearance of the three men was conducted by the investigative department of the district prosecutor's office in Argun.

On 20 September 2003 the investigative department sent a request for information to the Ministry of Internal Affairs (MVD) of the Chechen Republic. The letter requested information about the detention of the three men on 16 December 2001 and their subsequent disappearance.

On 22 September 2003 the investigative department received a response from the MVD stating that on 16 December 2001 the three men had been detained by unidentified armed persons in the village of Khasavyurt, Dagestan. According to the MVD, the detainees had been taken to the Argun district of Chechnya and on 18 December 2001 their bodies had been found in the village of Bamut, Argun district. The MVD stated that it had opened a criminal investigation into the incident but had not been able to establish the identity of the perpetrators.

B.  Relevant domestic law and practice

1.  The 1997 Criminal Code

19.  Article 44(1) of the 1997 Criminal Code provides:

“A person who has been sentenced to imprisonment may be deprived of his liberty only after the expiry of the term for which he was sentenced. The execution of a sentence of imprisonment may be suspended only if the person is a national of the respondent State and he undertakes to leave the territory of the respondent State.”

20.  Article 44(3) reads:

“If the person is a national of the respondent State, the execution of the sentence may be suspended provided that he undertakes to leave the territory of the respondent State.”

The court rejected these arguments. It noted that the applicants had not provided any evidence to support their allegations of inhuman and degrading treatment. It also noted that the applicants had not explained why they could not have been detained in a larger cell, and that they had not explained why they could not have been provided with adequate medical care if they had requested it. The court further noted that the applicants had not provided any evidence to support their allegation that they had been held in detention for longer than was necessary to complete the investigation and to prepare for trial.

The court concluded that the length of the detention was necessary to ensure the proper administration of justice and that the applicants had not been subjected to inhuman or degrading treatment.

III.  APPLICATION OF ARTICLE 3 OF THE CONVENTION

The applicants argued that their detention had subjected them to inhuman and degrading treatment in breach of Article 3 of the Convention.

The Court reiterated that Article 3 of the Convention prohibits in absolute terms torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Court noted that the applicants had not provided any evidence to support their allegations of inhuman or degrading treatment, and that they had not explained why they could not have been detained in a larger cell or provided with adequate

It further noted that the applicant had not been involved in the planning or execution of the crime. The court found that the applicant had not been aware that the cars had been stolen and had not known that the cars were stolen when he had helped to hide them. The applicant argued that he had exhausted domestic remedies. He had applied for compensation from the State for the damage caused to his health. However, he had not been informed about the outcome of the investigation.

B.  The Court’s assessment

The Court reiterates that in the context of Article 3 of the Convention, the requirement to exhaust domestic remedies means that the applicant must have recourse to such remedies as are available and sufficient in the domestic legal order to enable the domestic courts to deliver a final judgment in respect of the matter (see, among other authorities, L.C.B. v. the United Kingdom, no. 37244/97, § 61, ECHR 2000-III).

In the present case, the applicant had applied for compensation for the damage caused to his health. The Ministry of Internal Affairs had rejected his claim. He had also complained to the Prosecutor’s Office about the conditions of his detention in the punishment cell with Mr Ye. However, he had not been informed about the outcome of the investigation. B.  Relevant domestic law and practice

38.  The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge, BAMF) is responsible for examining applications for asylum and residence permits.

39.  According to the Federal Asylum Procedure Act (Asylverfahrensgesetz, AsylG), an applicant may be expelled if there are objective grounds for doing so, namely if the applicant has been convicted of a criminal offence or if there are reasons for expulsion on grounds of public policy or national security.

40.  Under section 31(1) of the AsylG, the expulsion of an asylum seeker is not permitted if the applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution in his country of origin.

41.  Under section 31(2) of the AsylG, the expulsion of a person who has been granted asylum is not permitted if there are substantial grounds for believing that the person would be in danger of persecution in the country of origin.

42.  Under section 31(3) of the AsylG, the expulsion of a person who has been granted a residence permit is not permitted if there are substantial grounds for believing that the person would be in danger of persecution in the country of origin.

43.  Under section 31(4) of the AsylG, the expulsion of a person who has been granted a residence permit is not permitted if there are substantial grounds for believing that the person would be exposed to serious harm in the country of origin.

The applicant complained under Article 5 § 1 (c) of the Convention that his arrest on 16 September 1998 had been based on insufficient grounds.

The Court reiterated that the power of arrest under Article 5 § 1 (c) of the Convention was a power of preventive detention, which could only be exercised in respect of a person for whom there was a real and sufficient ground for considering that his detention was necessary to prevent him from committing an offence or to ensure that he appeared at trial.

The Court considered that the discovery of the gun cartridges in the applicant’s car could not in itself justify his arrest on 16 September 1998, since the cartridges could have been planted there. In the absence of any other evidence, the Court found that the grounds on which the applicant had been arrested on 16 September 1998 had been insufficient.

The Court therefore held that there had been a violation of Article 5 § 1 (c) of the Convention.

The book is also replete with references to the Front National’s racist and xenophobic rhetoric, which is described in the most explicit terms: ‘[...] The Front National is a racist party, and its leader is a racist, and that’s that. [...] The Front National is a party of hate, and its leader is a man of hate, and that’s that.’
In conclusion, the author’s intention was to write a satire, but, in doing so, he went beyond the limits of acceptable freedom of expression, in particular by making allegations which, although they were not directed against Jean-Marie Le Pen personally, were clearly aimed at the Front National and its ideology.
In the present case, the Court considers that the expression at issue falls within the scope of Article 10 of the Convention, as it concerns a matter of public interest, namely the political ideology of the Front National and the role of its leader in promoting racist and xenophobic ideas.
However, the Court also considers that the expression at issue goes beyond the permissible limits of Article 10, in that it amounts to defamation, in particular in the context of the book as a whole, which is a work of fiction that, in addition to its satirical elements, contains a number of allegations which, although they are presented as fictional, are in fact based on real events and which, in the Court’s view, are capable of causing serious harm to the reputation of the Front National and Jean-Marie Le Pen.
Therefore, the Court concludes that the domestic courts did not violate the applicant’s right to freedom of expression under Article 10 of the Convention.

The investigation also found that the chief of staff of the UGA and the chief of staff of the Internal Troops Alliance in the Northern Caucasus had failed to take measures to prevent the use of force against civilians by their subordinates.  The investigation was closed in September 2000.  The charges against the military officers were dropped.

On 17 January 2001, the military prosecutor of the Northern Caucasus Military District opened a criminal investigation against Major General Aleksandr Kuznetsov, the commander of the 11th Separate Motorized Rifle Brigade (командир 11-й отдельной мотострелковой бригады), for exceeding his authority, abuse of power, and negligence.  The investigation was conducted by the military prosecutor of the Northern Caucasus Military District. The order stated that the military operation was to be carried out in accordance with the rules of military engagement, but in fact, the military used excessive force against civilians, including women and children.  The investigation also found that Major General Kuznetsov had failed to take measures to prevent the use of force against civilians by his subordinates.  The investigation was closed in March 2001. The Court notes that the right to a fair trial includes the right to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of one's defence (see, among other authorities, Article 6 § 3 (b) of the Convention). The right to consult and make copies of documents in the case file is an essential part of the right to prepare a defence effectively. In this connection, the Court has found that the right to consult the case file must be effective in practice, and that the time allowed for that purpose must be sufficient to enable the applicant to read and understand the documents concerned (see, for example, the case of Kostovski v. the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, no. 21974/02, § 33, 28 October 2005).

It found that the order of 20 February 1998 did not require the applicant to reside in a particular commune, but merely required him to reside in the Rhône département. The notice of expulsion was valid because it had been served before the judgment of the Lyons Administrative Court had become final.

3.2.  In the spring of 2009 the applicant was informed that he was suspected of having committed a crime under Article 210 of the Criminal Code of Georgia (illegal trafficking in narcotic drugs). He was summoned to appear before the investigative committee of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia on 27 April 2009. He failed to appear, as he was at that time in Russia.

3.3.  On 21 May 2009 the Georgian authorities issued a European Arrest Warrant (“EAW”) for the applicant, requesting his arrest and extradition to Georgia. The EAW was forwarded to the Russian authorities on 23 May 2009.

He was informed of the EAW and of the crime for which he was suspected in Georgia. He was taken to the FSB office in Nizhny Novgorod, where he was interrogated and questioned about the allegations. He denied any involvement in the crime.

3.5.  On 28 May 2009 the applicant was brought before the Nizhny Novgorod Regional Court, which considered the Georgian EAW. The court examined the EAW and the documents accompanying it, including the case file from the investigation into the crime committed in Georgia. The applicant was not represented by a lawyer at the hearing. The court found that the EAW complied with the relevant legal provisions and that there was no reason to refuse its execution. [2]  The offshore industry has for many years used tables developed for military use. However, the tables have been modified to suit the offshore industry. The main modifications are the use of increased O2 content in the breathing gas and the addition of a safety factor to the ascent rate.
[3]  The use of increased O2 content in the breathing gas reduces the decompression time. However, this also increases the risk of oxygen toxicity, which can manifest itself in different ways, including convulsions, unconsciousness, and death.
[4]  The safety factor in the ascent rate is intended to provide a margin of safety in case the diver experiences symptoms of oxygen toxicity. The safety factor is expressed as a percentage increase in the ascent rate above the rate indicated in the table. The safety factor is typically set at 25% for commercial diving in 200 m water depth.
[5]  The 2003 Diving Regulations for the North Sea, which came into force on 1 January 2004, require the use of decompression tables that are based on the latest scientific knowledge and that are approved by the national authorities. The regulations also specify that the decompression tables must be regularly reviewed and updated, and that the diver must be informed of the decompression requirements prior to the dive.
[6]  The 2003 Diving Regulations for the North Sea do not prescribe a specific safety factor for the ascent rate. However, they do require that the decompression tables must be based on the latest scientific knowledge and that they must be approved by the national authorities. It is up to the national authorities to decide whether to include a safety factor in the ascent rate and, if so, what the level of the safety factor should be.
[7]  The Norwegian Petroleum Directorate has issued a circular that recommends a safety factor of 30% for the ascent rate in offshore diving operations in Norway. This is higher than the 25% safety factor that is commonly used in the North Sea. The circular also recommends the use of decompression tables that are based on the latest scientific knowledge and that have been approved by the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate.”

The United States does not dispute that Spain has jurisdiction to prosecute Lopez Elorza for the crimes for which he is currently being prosecuted in Spain.  The United States, however, is concerned that if Lopez Elorza is sentenced to a term of imprisonment in Spain, he may be subject to deportation from Spain to Mexico upon completion of his sentence.  The United States believes that, if deported to Mexico, Lopez Elorza would face a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment.  In light of this concern, the United States has requested that Spain agree to a transfer of Lopez Elorza to the United States for the purpose of serving his sentence there, rather than in Spain.
The United States is not seeking to interfere with Spain’s criminal justice system.  The United States has no objection to Lopez Elorza being prosecuted in Spain for the crimes for which he is currently being prosecuted.  The United States simply requests that, if Lopez Elorza is sentenced to a term of imprisonment in Spain, he be transferred to the United States to serve that sentence.
The United States is not seeking to dictate the length of any sentence that may be imposed on Lopez Elorza in Spain.  The United States recognizes that Spain has the authority to determine the length of any sentence that it deems appropriate.  The United States is only seeking to ensure that Lopez Elorza will not be deported to Mexico to face a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment upon completion of his sentence.

These statements were not disclosed to the defence until 2002, and the defence sought to adduce them at the retrial. The trial judge refused to admit them, on the grounds that they were inadmissible hearsay, and that the appellant had not made any application to adduce them at the original trial.

[14] The statements in question were made by El Fahi to the police in the course of an interview on 11 March 1996. The interview was recorded on tape and a transcript was prepared. The statements made by El Fahi during this interview were not disclosed to the defence until 2002. The defence sought to adduce them at the retrial, but the trial judge refused to admit them, on the grounds that they were inadmissible hearsay and that no application had been made to admit them at the original trial.

[15] The defence sought to argue that the statements were admissible under the “exceptions to the hearsay rule” set out in section 118 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Act 1984. The trial judge rejected this argument, holding that the statements were inadmissible hearsay because they were not made for the purpose of being given in evidence at the trial of the person making them. We agree with the trial judge.

[16] The statements were made in the course of an interview conducted by the police, for the purpose of investigating the bombing. They were not made for the purpose of being given in evidence at the trial of El Fahi or of anyone else. The fact that they were recorded and a transcript prepared does not change this. The fact that they might have been used in evidence at a later trial does not change this either. The Court considered that the applicant's reasons for not doing so (that he had been promised payment by the head of administration) were not sufficient to absolve him from his responsibility to apply to the court within the statutory time limit.

The Court of Appeal's decision is in line with the established case law of the European Court of Human Rights. Turkey (Application no. 16033/90, Commission decision of 25 March 1993, Decisions and Reports (DR) 73, p. 132), the Commission held that the applicants had not exhausted domestic remedies because they had not brought their claims before the domestic courts within the time limits set by the Turkish Code of Civil Procedure. 140,000 cubic metre LNG carriers, which will be used at Milford Haven, are designed to withstand a collision with a vessel of the same size. LNG itself does not explode or burn under normal conditions. It is cooled to a temperature of around minus 162 degrees centigrade, and the pressure is kept at around 140 pounds per square inch. These conditions are far below the temperature and pressure at which LNG can ignite. In fact, LNG is less volatile than water, which is why it is transported in insulated containers.
Could a fire on an LNG carrier cause the LNG to ignite?
If a fire were to break out on an LNG carrier, the first priority would be to evacuate the crew and ensure that the fire was extinguished as quickly as possible. The LNG itself would not ignite under the conditions on the carrier. However, if the fire were to spread to the insulation on the LNG tank, it could cause the tank to heat up. If the temperature reached around minus 120 degrees centigrade, the LNG could start to boil off and form a flammable vapour. This vapour could ignite if it came into contact with a source of ignition, such as a spark from the fire. However, the LNG carriers are designed with safety features to prevent this from happening. The insulation on the tanks is fire resistant and the carriers have a number of safety systems to prevent a fire from spreading to the LNG tanks.
Could an earthquake cause an LNG tank to rupture?
An earthquake could potentially cause a rupture in an LNG tank, but the risk is very low. The tanks are designed to withstand earthquakes of a certain magnitude. The LNG terminal at Milford Haven will be located in an area with a low risk of earthquakes. The tanks will also be surrounded by a bund wall, which is designed to contain any spillage in the unlikely event of a rupture.
Could a terrorist attack cause an LNG tank to explode?
An LNG tank cannot be exploded by a terrorist attack or any other means. LNG is not a bomb and it cannot be ignited under normal conditions. The terrorist threat is taken very seriously by ExxonMobil and the security arrangements at the LNG terminal

Şuşa, Göle and Akhalkalaki were formed in the late 18th century.

In the 19th century, the region was a part of the Russian Empire, and was known as the Kars Oblast. The 1877-1878 Russian-Turkish War resulted in the transfer of Kars and the surrounding area to the Russian Empire. The Kars Oblast was then a part of the Tiflis Governorate. In 1918, after the fall of the Russian Empire, the Kars Oblast was part of the short-lived Democratic Republic of Armenia. In 1920, the region was invaded by the Red Army, and was then part of the Soviet Union. In 1936, the Kars Oblast was divided between the Georgian SSR and the Armenian SSR.

In 1989, during the Soviet period, the Kars Oblast was the site of the Kars earthquake, which killed over 1,000 people.

In 1991, following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Kars Oblast became part of the newly independent Republic of Armenia. In 1993, following the war in Nagorno-Karabakh, the Kars Oblast was transferred to Turkey. The transfer was not recognized by the international community, and the region remains a subject of dispute between Armenia and Turkey.

The Kars Oblast is now part of the Turkish province of Kars. The population is predominantly Turkish, with small Armenian and Kurdish minorities. The economy is based on agriculture, livestock raising, and industry. The main industries are food processing, textiles, and metalworking. The region is known for its natural beauty, with mountains, forests, and lakes. The city of Kars is the largest city in the region and is known for its historic architecture and cultural heritage.

The military prosecutor’s office requested the Prosecutor General’s Office of the Russian Federation to revoke the decision to suspend the investigation and to order the investigation to be resumed.

On 25 July 2001, the Prosecutor General’s Office of the Russian Federation revoked the decision to suspend the investigation and ordered the investigation to be resumed.

The investigation was resumed and the military prosecutor’s office of the 1st Military District carried out investigative measures in the town of [deleted]. The investigation established that the helicopter squadron had indeed been involved in the attack on the Niva vehicle, and that the personnel of the helicopter squadron had opened fire on the Niva vehicle with automatic weapons.

The military prosecutor’s office of the 1st Military District brought charges against the personnel of the helicopter squadron for the crime of intentional destruction or damage to property committed by a group of persons using firearms or other weapons, as provided for in Article 149 of the Russian Criminal Code.

The investigation was completed on 26 September 2001, and the case file was sent to the military court of the 1st Military District for consideration.

The military court of the 1st Military District held a hearing on 17 October 2001 and found the defendants guilty as charged. The court sentenced them to various terms of imprisonment.

The investigation and trial were conducted in accordance with Russian law. The decision to suspend the investigation was based on the available evidence at the time and was revoked when new evidence emerged. The investigation was resumed and the defendants were brought to justice.

Therefore, the decision to suspend the investigation did not violate the applicant’s right to an effective investigation as guaranteed by Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights.

The applicant’s defence counsel was also subjected to threats and intimidation.

42.  The applicant was found guilty on 11 counts and sentenced to a total of 23 years’ imprisonment. He was acquitted on 2 counts. The judgment was handed down on 21 June 2005.

43.  The applicant lodged an appeal on 28 June 2005. 44.  The Ajarian High Court upheld the judgment on 11 July 2006. It found that the evidence against the applicant had been sufficient and that the sentence was justified.

45.  The applicant lodged a cassation appeal on 13 July 2006. He argued that the investigation had been conducted improperly, that the trial had been unfair, and that the sentence was excessive.

46.  The Supreme Court of Georgia dismissed the cassation appeal on 28 July 2006. It found that the investigation had been conducted in accordance with the law and that the applicant’s defence counsel had been able to put forward a proper defence. It also found that the sentence was not disproportionate to the offences committed.

47.  The applicant lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights on 11 October 2006. He complained under Article 3 of the Convention about the conditions of detention in the Ajarian pre-trial detention centre, and under Articles 5, 6 and 13 about the fairness of the proceedings against him.

Land B, the Court considered that the Freeport legislation did not make any provision for compensation in respect of land acquired for the purpose of the Freeport and that the taking of Land B was not for the purpose of the Freeport.  The Court held that the taking of Land B was not Convention compatible and that the State was obliged to pay compensation to the Claimant.

The Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Constitutional Court and the State appealed to the Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court held that the Constitutional Court had erred in law in its interpretation of the Freeport legislation and that the taking of Land B was for the purpose of the Freeport.  The Supreme Court also held that the State was entitled to take Land B without compensation and that the Freeport legislation did not infringe the Claimant’s property rights under the European Convention on Human Rights.

The Claimant was entitled to claim damages under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act 1976 and the State submitted that the Claimant was not entitled to claim damages as the Supreme Court decision was final and binding and that the Claimant had not exhausted all available domestic remedies.  The Court held that the Claimant had exhausted all available domestic remedies and that the State was liable to pay damages in the sum of US$ 2.6 million to the Claimant.

The Court also considered the Claimant’s claim for interest and held that the Claimant was entitled to interest at the rate of 10% per annum from the date of the judgment of the Constitutional Court.  The Court also considered the Claimant’s claim for costs and held that the Claimant was entitled to costs on the standard basis.

The judgment of the Supreme Court is available here.

Article 332

"1.  The State may acquire ownership of immovable property for public needs only in the following cases:

a)  for the construction, extension, repair, or maintenance of public buildings, roads, railways, waterways, airports, airfields, air navigation facilities, power lines, and other similar installations;

b)  for the implementation of measures to prevent natural disasters and to protect the population and property against natural disasters;

c)  for the implementation of measures to protect the environment and to ensure public health and safety;

d)  for the implementation of measures to ensure the safety of the State and the protection of the constitutional order.

2.  The State may acquire ownership of immovable property for public needs only on the basis of a court decision or a decision of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan, taken in accordance with the procedure provided for in the present Code and other legislative acts.

The Ministry of Defence refused to provide the information, citing national security interests.  The investigation also requested information from the Ministry of the Interior regarding the number of persons who had been granted amnesty for their participation in the operations, but the Ministry did not provide the information.  The investigation also sought information from the State Prosecutor’s Office regarding the results of investigations into the alleged war crimes committed during the operations, but the State Prosecutor’s Office did not provide the information.

The investigation found that during the operations, members of the military and police forces committed acts of violence against civilians, including murder, torture, rape, and looting.  The investigation identified 37 victims and 13 suspects.  The investigation found that the operations were not conducted in accordance with the laws and customs of war, and that the military and police forces did not distinguish between combatants and civilians.  The investigation also found that the military and police forces did not take adequate measures to protect civilians, and that they did not issue warnings before launching attacks.

The investigation recommended that the State Prosecutor’s Office initiate criminal proceedings against the suspects identified in the investigation, and that the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of the Interior be held accountable for failing to ensure that the military and police forces conducted the operations in accordance with the laws and customs of war.  The investigation also recommended that the State Prosecutor’s Office request assistance from international organizations to conduct further investigations and identify additional suspects.

The investigation was closed in 2019 due to lack of progress in the implementation of the recommendations.

At about 8:30 p.m. Mr Cox's wife heard him making strange noises in his sleep.  She went to his bedside and found him unconscious.  She called an ambulance and Mr Cox was taken to hospital. The compensation was to be paid in the form of “material assistance” (“pomoc materialna”).  The Polish State was to pay compensation for losses suffered during the war, including the value of lost property, to persons who had been repatriated from the territories of the former Soviet Union to their former homes in Poland.  The compensation was to be paid in the form of “material assistance”, which was defined as “goods, food, clothing, footwear, bedclothes, household utensils, agricultural implements, livestock, or money, in the amount determined by the Polish State” (see, e.g., the Agreement between the Polish Committee of National Liberation and the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, paragraph 4).  The Polish State was also to pay compensation for the losses suffered by persons who had been repatriated from the territories of the former Soviet Union to Poland, but who had not returned to their former homes, in the form of “material assistance” or in the form of “money” (see, e.g., the Agreement between the Polish Committee of National Liberation and the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, paragraph 5).

On 21 April 1976 Mr Vilnes was employed by the diving company Sørensen & Co. as a diver. The company was contracted by the Danish State to carry out underwater work on the Danish side of Øresund. The work was carried out in accordance with the Danish Maritime Safety Act. Mr Vilnes and his colleague were to carry out work on the Danish side of the border, but they were not required to obtain a permit from the Swedish authorities. The work consisted of removing a concrete block weighing approximately 1,500 kg, which had fallen from a bridge into the sea.

On 23 April 1976 Mr Vilnes and his colleague were diving in the vicinity of the concrete block. At approximately 11 a.m. Mr Vilnes saw a Swedish police boat approaching, which was followed by a Swedish diving boat. The Swedish diving boat was manned by two divers, who were later identified as Mr Svensson and Mr Karlsson. The Swedish police boat was manned by a police officer and a Swedish customs officer. The Swedish authorities demanded that Mr Vilnes and his colleague stop their work. Mr Vilnes refused to comply with the demand, as he believed that they were carrying out work on the Danish side of the border and were therefore not subject to Swedish jurisdiction. The Swedish authorities then informed the Danish authorities, who ordered Mr Vilnes and his colleague to stop their work. Mr Vilnes and his colleague complied with the order and left the site.

The following day, on 24 April 1976, Mr Vilnes and his colleague were again working in the vicinity of the concrete block. At approximately 11 a.m. they were approached by the Swedish police boat, which was manned by the same police officer and customs officer as the previous day. The Swedish authorities again demanded that Mr Vilnes and his colleague stop their work. Mr Vilnes again refused to comply, but this time he was arrested and taken aboard the Swedish police boat. The Swedish authorities also arrested his colleague. Mr Vilnes was taken to the Swedish police station in Malmö, where he was detained for approximately five hours. He was then released without charge.

The applicants were arrested on 15 and 16 January 1993.  They were detained in Ankara and Istanbul for several months.  The trial began on 28 September 1993 and lasted until 14 January 1994.  The applicants were represented by counsel.  The prosecution presented evidence consisting mainly of statements by witnesses, intercepted telephone conversations, and documents.  The applicants did not call any witnesses.  The court found all the applicants guilty of being subsidiary members of the PKK and sentenced them to various terms of imprisonment.  The sentences ranged from 15 years and six months for İmam Şahin to three years and six months for Naciye Yılmaz.  The judgment was delivered on 14 January 1994.

The applicants appealed against their convictions and sentences to the Ankara Regional Court of Appeal.  The appeal was dismissed on 14 October 1994.  They then appealed on points of law to the Supreme Court of Appeals.  The Supreme Court of Appeals upheld the convictions and sentences on 12 January 1996.  The applicants were granted leave to appeal on points of law to the Constitutional Court.  The Constitutional Court upheld the convictions and sentences on 12 March 1997.

The applicants complained under Article 10 of the Convention about the interference with their freedom of expression.  They argued that the statements made by them had been in the context of their professional activities as lawyers and journalists and that the criminalisation of their activities had had a chilling effect on their right to freedom of expression.

The applicants also complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention about the length of the proceedings.  They argued that the trial had lasted for over a year and that they had been detained for several months prior to the trial.

The applicants further complained under Article 5 § 1 of the Convention about their detention.  They argued that their detention had been arbitrary and that there had been no sufficient legal basis for it.

The applicants, who were represented by Mr V. Shapovalov, a lawyer practising in Vladivostok, complained under Article 34 of the Convention that the domestic courts had failed to provide an effective remedy in respect of their complaints about the Vladivostok city authorities’ failure to clear snow and ice from the pavement in question.

The Court notes that the applicants’ complaints under Article 34 of the Convention raise issues which are closely linked to their complaints under Article 2 of the Convention. In the light of the Court’s findings under Article 2, it is not necessary to examine separately the complaints under Article 34.

II.  ALLEGED VIOLATION OF ARTICLE 2 OF THE CONVENTION

3.  Submissions by the parties

3.1.  The applicants

The applicants submitted that the Vladivostok city authorities had failed to take the necessary measures to ensure that the pavement in question was kept free of ice and snow, and that this had led to the applicants’ accidents. They argued that the authorities had been aware of the dangerous condition of the pavement, but had failed to take any steps to remedy it. They also contended that the authorities had not taken any measures to warn pedestrians of the danger. The applicants maintained that the Vladivostok city authorities had had a positive obligation under Article 2 of the Convention to take preventive measures to ensure that the pavement was kept safe for pedestrian use. They argued that the Russian authorities had failed to comply with their positive obligations under Article 2 of the Convention, and that the domestic courts had failed to provide an effective remedy for this violation.

3.2.  The Russian Government

The Russian Government submitted that the Vladivostok city authorities had not had any obligation to clear the pavement in question of snow and ice, as it was not a public thoroughfare. label: Europe

27 EU Member States.

In conclusion, the Court of Cassation confirmed the decisions of the lower courts and held that the Italian Constitution and the European Convention on Human Rights did not require the recognition of same-sex marriages. The Court further stated that the legislation in question did not create an unreasonable discrimination, as homosexual unions could not be considered equivalent to marriages between a man and a woman.

### Comment

The decision of the Court of Cassation is a disappointing one, as it further confirms the absence of recognition of same-sex marriage in Italy. It is worth noting that the Court of Cassation did not examine the compatibility of the Italian legislation with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, as the parties did not raise this issue. The judgment also does not provide any analysis of the impact of the CJEU’s judgment in Coman on the Italian legislation.

The Court of Cassation also seems to overlook the fact that the CJEU has recognized the right to free movement for same-sex spouses, which implies that the Member State of residence must recognize the validity of the same-sex marriage concluded in another Member State.

The decision is also significant as it comes after the Italian Constitutional Court’s judgment in the 2015 Case No. 281, which ruled that the Italian Constitution did not require the recognition of same-sex marriages, but left the door open for the Parliament to legislate on the matter.

The Court of Cassation’s decision is also in contrast with the position of the Italian Government, which has recently signaled its intention to introduce a bill on same-sex civil unions.

### Source

Corte di Cassazione, Sezione I, Giudizio n. 10532 del 22.12.2016, available at: http://www.cassazione.it/documents/10180/0/Giudizio_n._10532_del_22_dicembre_2016.pdf/718491e8-22f6-4c9e-838d-32b15278479a.

I.  ALLEGED VIOLATION OF ARTICLE 5 § 1 OF THE CONVENTION

25.  The applicant complained that his detention in Drin was in breach of Article 5 § 1 of the Convention, which reads as follows:

“1.  Everybody has the right to liberty and security of person. No one shall be deprived of his liberty save in the following cases and in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law:
(e) the lawful arrest or detention of a person effected for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority on reasonable suspicion of having committed an offence or when it is reasonably considered necessary to prevent his committing an offence or fleeing after having done so;
(f) the detention of persons after conviction by a competent court or having of a sentence of a competent court suspended on condition of the execution of the sentence or of the performance of another penalty.”

A.  Admissibility

26.  The Government submitted that the applicant’s complaint was inadmissible because he had not exhausted domestic remedies. They argued that the applicant had failed to challenge the lawfulness of his detention before the competent domestic courts and that the courts had not been seised of the matter.

27.  The Court notes that the applicant did not challenge the lawfulness of his detention before the domestic courts. However, it is clear from the case file that the applicant’s detention was subject to judicial review, as required by Article 5 § 1 of the Convention. The Vareš Social Work Centre had informed the Visoko Municipal Court that it considered that the applicant’s continued placement in Drin was in his best interest for reasons of social protection. The applicant had been informed of this and had had an opportunity to challenge the decision before the municipal court.

28.  The Court further notes that the applicant had challenged the lawfulness of his detention before the Court. In the circumstances, the Court finds that the applicant had exhausted domestic remedies.

2.1  The applicant complained that the apprehension, detention and ill-treatment of her husband and her sister-in-law constituted inhuman and degrading treatment in breach of Article 3 of the Convention.

2.3  The Court reiterates that the physical and mental integrity of a person is a fundamental value protected under Article 3 of the Convention.  The prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment covers not only acts causing physical or mental pain, but also those which are likely to humiliate or debase a person.  In the present case, the applicant alleged that her husband and sister-in-law had been subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment during their detention.  She did not allege that they had been subjected to physical ill-treatment, but rather that they had been detained in inhuman conditions, in breach of Article 3 of the Convention.

> Hizb ut-Tahrir’s position on violence is complicated. The group has denounced terrorism and has condemned the September 11 attacks. It also denounces the violence of Israel against Palestinians. But the group’s position on violence is not clear-cut. Hizb ut-Tahrir literature includes calls for jihad and the use of violence to bring about political change. The group does not advocate violence against civilians, but it does not condemn the use of violence against military targets in the context of armed struggles. It also encourages its members to engage in nonviolent protests and to use the ballot box to bring about political change.
>
> Hizb ut-Tahrir has been banned in several countries, including Germany, Russia, and China. The group’s activities have been restricted in other countries, including Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and Turkey. In some cases, the group has been accused of having links to violent extremist groups, such as al-Qaeda. However, there is no evidence that Hizb ut-Tahrir has engaged in or supported violence itself.
>
> Despite the controversy surrounding Hizb ut-Tahrir, it is important to recognize that the group’s members are entitled to the same protections as any other religious group. The right to freedom of religion includes the right to manifest that religion peacefully and publicly, as well as the right to organize and express political views in a peaceful and nonviolent manner. The persecution of Hizb ut-Tahrir members on the basis of their religious beliefs would be a violation of their fundamental human rights.

The U.S. government, like many others, has taken the position that Hizb ut-Tahrir is a political organization and not a religious one. The applicant complained under Article 9 of the Convention that the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina had discriminated against him by refusing to reinstate him in the 1999/2000 academic year and by failing to remove the public schools from the Archdiocese High School building in Travnik.

The Chamber found that the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina had violated the applicant’s right to freedom of religion under Article 9 of the Convention. It held that the Federation had failed to take adequate measures to prevent the use of the Archdiocese High School building by public schools, and that the applicant’s expulsion from the school had been a consequence of that failure.

The Chamber ordered the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure the relocation of the public schools housed in the Archdiocese High School building and to reinstate the applicant in the 1999/2000 academic year.

The applicant did not appeal the judgment.

18-hectare area surrounding the monument.

The monument was erected in 1957 in honor of the Soviet soldiers who died in the Battle of Stalingrad.  The monument consists of a 21-meter-high obelisk with a statue of a soldier on top.  The monument is surrounded by a park, which contains a number of monuments and memorial plaques dedicated to various units and individuals who fought in the Battle of Stalingrad.

The monument and its surroundings are of historical and cultural significance to the local population, as well as to the Russian people as a whole, since the Battle of Stalingrad was one of the most significant military engagements of World War II.  The monument is also an important symbol of the Soviet victory in the war and of the heroism and sacrifices of the Soviet soldiers who fought in the Battle of Stalingrad.

For these reasons, the destruction or damage of the monument and its surroundings would be a violation of the rights of the local population and of the Russian people to freedom of thought, conscience, and religion, as well as to the enjoyment of cultural heritage.  It would also be a violation of the provisions of the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, to which Russia is a party, and of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict, to which Russia is also a party.

Therefore, we urge the authorities of the Sovetskiy District and the city of Volgograd to take immediate steps to prevent the destruction or damage of the monument and its surroundings, and to ensure that the local population and all interested parties are able to enjoy and appreciate this important historical and cultural site.

The applicants argued that the judgment was incompatible with Article 1 of Protocol No. 1, as it did not provide for the restitution of their property, and that it violated their right to the peaceful enjoyment of their possessions under Article 8 of the Convention. They submitted that the judgment was also contrary to the European Court of Human Rights’ case-law, in particular the judgment in the case of Mellacher and Others v. Austria (Application no. 10261/83, Commission decision of 18 February 1986, Decisions and Reports (DR) 42, p. 13, § 30).

The Court reiterated that the right to the peaceful enjoyment of possessions under Article 8 of the Convention did not preclude the State from taking measures to secure the general interest of the community, such as the expropriation of property, provided that the measures were not arbitrary or disproportionate. The Court further recalled that, in the context of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1, the concept of “possession” was not limited to ownership but also covered other forms of tenure or use, such as usufruct, lease or servitude. In this connection, the Court noted that the judgment in question had not deprived the applicants of their title deeds or of any right to use the disputed land, but had merely determined that the land had become public property, which meant that the municipality could use it for the benefit of the community. The Court thus considered that the judgment did not interfere with the applicants’ right to the peaceful enjoyment of their possessions under Article 8 of the Convention.

As to the argument that the judgment was contrary to the European Court of Human Rights’ case-law, the Court pointed out that the case-law cited by the applicants concerned the restitution of property that had been unlawfully expropriated, and did not concern the situation where the disputed land had become public property. The Court thus considered that the judgment in question was not incompatible with the European Court of Human Rights’ case-law.

According to the investigation, the servicemen involved in the kidnapping and subsequent deaths were from the 21st Motor Rifle Brigade of the Russian Federation's 58th Army. The servicemen were not identified, and no charges have been brought against them. The investigation into the deaths was closed in March 2002, and the families of the victims were not informed of the investigation's outcome.

In May 2002, the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) received an application from the Nasukhanov family. The application alleged that the Russian authorities had violated the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by failing to carry out an effective investigation into the deaths of the three men.

In its judgment of 28 November 2007, the ECHR found that there had been a violation of Article 2 (right to life) of the ECHR. The Court noted that the investigation into the deaths had been inadequate and that the authorities had failed to take adequate measures to protect the lives of the three men. The Court also found that the authorities had failed to carry out an effective investigation into the circumstances of the kidnapping, and that there had been no effective investigation into the involvement of the servicemen in the kidnapping and subsequent deaths.

The Court awarded damages of 30,000 euros to the Nasukhanov family. The Russian authorities have not yet paid the damages.

The Russian authorities have not taken any steps to bring those responsible for the deaths to justice.

Amnesty International calls on the Russian authorities to carry out a thorough and effective investigation into the deaths of the Nasukhanov brothers and their father, including the involvement of servicemen from the 21st Motor Rifle Brigade of the Russian Federation's 58th Army. The authorities should also ensure that those responsible are brought to justice in fair trials.

The MASC regulations sought to avoid any unduly adverse impact on the absent parent's new relationship and to achieve a fair balance between it and the children's needs. They were intended to provide a degree of certainty for both parents and to avoid the need for repeated applications to the court. The refusal decision was based on the fact that the applicant spouses did not have a secure livelihood and that they could not prove that they had sufficient resources to live in Estonia.  The decision further stated that the applicant wife had a residence permit in Denmark and that she could return there if she wished.  The applicant spouses appealed against the decision.

8.  On 28 February 2006 the Tallinn Administrative Court (Tartu Chamber) quashed the decision of 14 October 2005 and remitted the case for fresh consideration.  The court held that the refusal decision was based on insufficient evidence.  The court further held that the applicant spouses had a secure livelihood in Denmark and that they could prove that they had sufficient resources to live in Estonia.

The applicant spouses appealed against the decision.

10.  On 28 July 2006 the Tallinn Administrative Court (Harju Chamber) quashed the decision of 20 April 2006 and remitted the case for fresh consideration. The court further held that the applicant spouses had a secure livelihood in Denmark but that they could prove that they had sufficient resources to live in Estonia.

“1.  Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life, his home and his correspondence.

2.  There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well-being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.”

> The Court also referred to the fact that the applicant had not exhausted all the possibilities for obtaining medical treatment in the receiving State, even though it had to be accepted that the treatment available there was less effective than that in the Netherlands. The Court was of the view that the applicant should have availed himself of the assistance of the Dutch authorities in this regard. In this respect, the Court was not impressed by the fact that the applicant had been unable to obtain any information from the Dutch authorities as to the availability and cost of the medical treatment in question. It was also not swayed by the argument that the applicant's condition was such that he could not travel. The Court took the view that the applicant had not provided sufficient evidence to show that it would have been impossible for him to obtain the necessary medical treatment in the receiving State.

> The Court's approach to the facts of this case is, I think, highly significant. It is a clear indication that the Convention cannot be used as a means of obtaining medical or other forms of assistance in the territory of a Contracting State. The fact that the applicant's condition was such that he could not travel to the receiving State was not considered to be a sufficient reason for refusing to expel him. The Court was also not swayed by the fact that the medical treatment available in the receiving State was less effective than that in the Netherlands. The applicant was expected to exhaust all possibilities for obtaining medical treatment in the receiving State before seeking to rely on the Convention.

> In my opinion, the Court's approach to the facts of this case is a welcome development. It is in line with the general principle that aliens who are subject to expulsion cannot claim any entitlement to remain in the territory of a Contracting State in order to continue to benefit from medical, social or other forms of assistance provided by the expelling State. This principle is an essential part of the Convention system and is necessary to ensure that Contracting States are not obliged to provide assistance to aliens who are not entitled to remain in their territory.

> In conclusion, I would hold that the expulsion of the applicant from the Netherlands in the circumstances of this case did not give rise to any violation of Article 3 of the Convention. The fact that the applicant's condition was such that he could not travel to the receiving State and that the medical treatment available there was less effective than that in the Netherlands

21. The applicant complains that the decision to discontinue the criminal investigation against the VCA violated her right to an effective remedy under Article 13 of the Convention. She argues that the decision was unjustified and that the investigation should have continued in order to establish the truth of the matter. She further argues that the decision was taken without her participation and that she was not informed of the decision in a timely manner.

A. Admissibility

1. The applicant complains that the decision to discontinue the criminal investigation against the VCA was unjustified. She argues that the investigation should have continued in order to establish the truth of the matter.

2. The Court reiterates that the Convention does not lay down any rules on the conduct of criminal investigations or the discretion to be exercised in deciding whether or not to institute criminal proceedings (see, for example, Hentrich v. Germany, 26 June 1996, § 44, Reports of Judgments and Decisions 1996-III). The decision to discontinue a criminal investigation is a matter for the national authorities and does not as such give rise to a violation of the Convention.

3. The applicant further argues that the decision was taken without sufficient evidence. She submits that the investigation should have continued in order to establish the truth of the matter.

4. The Court reiterates that the standard of proof required under Article 13 is not the same as that applicable in criminal proceedings. It is sufficient that the decision taken by the domestic authorities was based on an adequate and reasonable assessment of the relevant facts (see, for example, Kress v. France, 25 March 1993, § 37, Series A no. 260-B). In the present case, the domestic authorities decided to discontinue the criminal investigation on the grounds that the land reform in the 1960s had been carried out in accordance with the law and that the VCA's actions were based on that law. label: Europe
output:
1,000 pages long, about the history of Gazeta Wyborcza.
The book is called ‘Gazeta Wyborcza: The Truth About Gazeta Wyborcza’. It is a work of great importance for Polish journalism.
The author, Stanisław Remuszko, has worked for Gazeta Wyborcza since its inception in 1989. He was a member of the editorial board from 1993 to 1997. He was also the editor of the daily’s Sunday supplement, ‘Wiedza i Życie’ (‘Knowledge and Life’), from 1993 to 1994.
The book contains a great deal of previously unseen material. It includes interviews with over 100 people, including many journalists, who worked at Gazeta Wyborcza, as well as politicians and other public figures.
The book reveals the inner workings of Gazeta Wyborcza. It describes the newspaper’s relations with the Polish Social Democracy [Socjaldemokracja Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej, SLD] and the Democratic Left Alliance [Sojusz Lewicy Demokratycznej, SLD], as well as with the political parties and politicians of the right.
The book describes the newspaper’s relations with the Polish security services, the Internal Security Agency [Agencja Bezpieczeństwa Wewnętrznego, ABW] and the Security Service [Służba Bezpieczeństwa, SB], as well as with the secret services of other countries.
The book describes the newspaper’s relations with the Catholic Church, as well as with the media and the business world.
The book also describes the newspaper’s relations with the Polish state and the European Union.
The book is an important work for Polish journalism. It is an indispensable book for anyone who wants to understand the history of Gazeta Wyborcza and Polish journalism in general.
The book is available at all good bookstores and online at www.wydawnictwobuntu.pl.

The village of Kurşunlu is the larger of the two and has a population of approximately 1,200 people. The village is situated on a hillside and is surrounded by pine forests and olive groves. The main street is lined with shops, cafes and tea houses. The village has a mosque, a primary school, a health centre and a post office. There is also a weekly market on Thursdays.

The hamlet of Kayaş has a population of approximately 300 people and is situated on a hillside surrounded by pine forests. The hamlet has a mosque, a primary school and a health centre. There is a weekly market on Fridays.

Both Kurşunlu and Kayaş are popular tourist destinations and are known for their beautiful scenery, clean air and traditional Turkish village life. They are also popular with hikers and nature lovers due to their proximity to the pine forests and the Şahinler Lake.

The village of Kurşunlu is approximately 25 kilometres from the town of Çamlıca and 45 kilometres from the city of Adana. The hamlet of Kayaş is approximately 20 kilometres from Kurşunlu and 35 kilometres from Çamlıca.

Transportation to Kurşunlu and Kayaş is available by minibus or dolmuş from Çamlıca. There are also regular bus services from Adana to Çamlıca. Private cars and motorbikes can also be used to reach the villages.

Accommodation in Kurşunlu and Kayaş is available in guesthouses and pansiyons. There are also camping sites nearby for those who prefer to stay in tents.

In conclusion, Kurşunlu and Kayaş are beautiful and traditional Turkish villages located in a mountainous region of southern Turkey. They are popular tourist destinations and offer a peaceful and relaxing atmosphere for those seeking to escape the hustle and bustle of city life. With their clean air, beautiful scenery, and traditional Turkish village life, Kurşunlu and Kayaş are definitely worth a visit.

It is rumoured that the president will be moving to the Federal Chancellery, while his wife is said to be planning to move to the Belvedere Palace. This is a situation that would be unprecedented in the history of the Republic.
As far as the future accommodation of the president is concerned, it is true that there is a precedent for this. In 1957, Federal President Adolf Schärf lived in the Chancellery during his term of office. However, the reasons for this were different: he had been evicted from his home, the Schönbrunn Palace, by the Soviet occupying forces.
As for the Belvedere Palace, it is true that the president’s wife is a patron of the Belvedere Museum. But it is also true that the Federal Chancellery has its own guest apartments. The Belvedere Palace, on the other hand, is a public institution and is not intended to be used as private accommodation.
It is also said that the president and his wife are planning to move to separate apartments. If this were true, it would be the first time that a married couple have lived apart in the history of the Republic.
The question of the president’s future accommodation is not the only topic of discussion. There is also speculation about who will succeed him. According to rumour, the leading contender is the current Foreign Minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner. But there are also other names being mentioned.
One thing is clear: the presidential election campaign has already begun. And the rumours and gossip are only the beginning of the political fireworks display.”

The District Court found that Y. B. had not had capacity at the time of the transfer of the property to Kryvitska G.S. and Kryvitskyy Y.F. in 1992 and 1993. It was also found that Y. B. had died on 16 December 1998 and that her property, including the disputed part of the building, had passed to the State.

The police officers, who had been monitoring the MSZP demonstration, were alerted by the presence of the Árpád-striped flag, which is traditionally associated with the extreme right. The police officers approached the applicant and asked him to leave the area. The applicant refused and said that he was a Hungarian citizen and that he had the right to be there. The police officers then arrested him for refusing to comply with their lawful order.
The applicant was taken to the police station and charged with disobedience under section 310 of the Criminal Code. He was detained for two hours. The applicant lodged an appeal against the decision to detain him. The Budapest Municipal Court quashed the decision and ordered his release.
On 28 May 2007 the Budapest Metropolitan Court upheld the decision of the Budapest Municipal Court. The Budapest Metropolitan Court held that the police officers had acted lawfully in asking the applicant to leave the area, but that they had exceeded their powers in arresting him. The Budapest Metropolitan Court found that the applicant had not been in a position to leave the area without being arrested, as there had been a large crowd present and the police had cordoned off the area. The Budapest Metropolitan Court held that the applicant’s arrest had been disproportionate and therefore unjustified.
The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against the decision of the Budapest Metropolitan Court. The Budapest Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal on 23 October 2007.
The applicant lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights on 11 December 2007.
The applicant complained that his arrest and detention had violated his rights under Article 5 § 1 of the Convention.

The applicant is a Kurd and is a member of the Democratic Party of the Oppressed (DEP), a political party which advocates the rights of the Kurdish minority in Turkey.

On 14 January 1993, at around 11.30 a.m., a group of approximately 20 soldiers from the 3rd Infantry Regiment of the Turkish Army arrived at the applicant’s house in Türeli village. The soldiers had been informed that the applicant had been distributing DEP leaflets and that he had been seen carrying a Kalashnikov rifle. The applicant was not present at the time of the soldiers’ arrival.

The soldiers searched the applicant’s house and found, among other things, a Kalashnikov rifle, a DEP flag, a DEP party card, a DEP poster and a DEP leaflet. The applicant’s son, who was present during the search, was taken away by the soldiers for questioning.

The applicant returned home at around 3 p.m. and was arrested by the soldiers on suspicion of being a member of the PKK (Kurdistan Workers’ Party), a terrorist organisation banned in Turkey, and of having committed acts of terrorism. The applicant was taken to the military garrison in Türeli village, where he was interrogated. He was not informed of the reasons for his arrest or of the charges against him. He was beaten during the interrogation and was forced to sign a statement in which he confessed to having been a member of the PKK and to having committed acts of terrorism. The applicant was subsequently taken to the Şanlıurfa Police Station, where he was detained for three days. During this period he was again beaten and was forced to sign a statement in which he confessed to having committed acts of terrorism.

On 16 January 1993, the applicant was taken to the Şanlıurfa Military Court. He was charged with being a member of the PKK and with having committed acts of terrorism. The applicant denied the charges. The applicant’s defence counsel was not present at the hearing. The applicant was remanded in custody.

The Allied forces did not enter Constantinople until 13 November 1918.
The Treaty of Sèvres, signed on 10 August 1920, provided:
“Article 17.  The Turkish Government will take immediate steps to secure the evacuation of all foreign troops from all parts of Turkish territory, except Constantinople and the European portion of the Thracian frontier, where the presence of foreign troops will be permitted under the conditions of the present Treaty.
“Article 18.  The Turkish Government will take immediate steps to secure the evacuation of all foreign troops from the Dardanelles and the Bosphorus, except those stationed at the forts and strategic points to be demilitarized under the conditions of the present Treaty.
“Article 22.  The Turkish Government will take immediate steps to secure the evacuation of all foreign troops from the Black Sea coast of Turkey, except those stationed at the forts and strategic points to be demilitarized under the conditions of the present Treaty.”
The Treaty of Sèvres was never ratified by the Turkish Parliament, and the Turkish National Movement, under the leadership of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, rejected it.  The Turkish National Movement, with the support of the Allied Powers, established the Turkish Republic on 29 October 1923.  The Treaty of Lausanne, signed on 24 July 1923, replaced the Treaty of Sèvres.  Article 11 of the Treaty of Lausanne provided:
“Article 11.  The Turkish Government will take immediate steps to secure the evacuation of all foreign troops from all parts of Turkish territory, except Constantinople, the European portion of the Thracian frontier, and the Dardanelles and the Bosphorus, where the presence of foreign troops will be permitted under the conditions of the present Treaty.

The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact was signed in Moscow on 23 August 1939.  The following day, on 24 August 1939, the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland from the west and the east, respectively.  On 1 September 1939, Britain and France declared war on Germany.

On 28 September 1939, the Soviet Union attacked Finland in what became known as the Winter War.  The Finns resisted fiercely and, despite the overwhelming numerical superiority of the Red Army, the Soviet Union was unable to capture the Finnish capital, Helsinki.  The war ended on 13 March 1940, when the Soviet Union signed a peace treaty with Finland, which included ceding the Karelian Isthmus and other territories to the Soviet Union.

On 22 June 1941, Nazi Germany invaded the Soviet Union.  The German forces initially made significant gains, but the Soviet Union was able to halt the German advance at the Battle of Moscow in December 1941.  The Soviet Union then began to push the German forces back, culminating in the capture of Berlin in April 1945.  The Soviet Union suffered enormous losses during the war, with an estimated 26 million deaths.

On 27 June 1945, the Soviet Union, the United States, the United Kingdom, and China signed the Moscow Declaration, which provided for the unconditional surrender of the Axis powers and the establishment of the United Nations.  The Soviet Union emerged from the war as one of the two superpowers, along with the United States.

The Soviet Union continued to expand its influence in Eastern Europe after the war, establishing satellite states in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria, and Albania.  The Soviet Union also established a sphere of influence in Eastern Europe through the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (COMECON), which was established in 1949 as an alternative to the Western-dominated European Economic Community.

2.  Relevant domestic law

2.1.  The Assemblies Act

The Assemblies Act (Law No. 120-XIII of 18 May 1995) regulates the holding of public assemblies and provides for the procedures to be followed in that connection. It entered into force on 21 May 1995.

Article 1(1) defines a public assembly as "any gathering of persons in a public place, organised for the purpose of expressing their views, including peaceful demonstrations, processions, pickets, meetings and rallies".

Article 2(1) sets out the general rule that public assemblies must be authorised by the competent authorities. However, article 12(5) provides that if an application for authorisation has not been examined within fifteen days from the date of submission, the organisers may hold the assembly without such authorisation.

Article 11(1) requires the organisers of a public assembly to submit an application to the competent authorities at least fifteen days before the planned assembly. The application must include the date, time and place of the assembly, the number of participants expected, the means of transport to be used, and the name and contact details of the organiser.

Article 13(1) sets out the grounds on which an application for authorisation may be refused. These include the threat to public order, public health or safety, the protection of national security, and the need to prevent crime.

Article 15(1) provides that the competent authorities may, at their discretion, impose conditions on the holding of a public assembly, such as the route to be followed by the demonstrators, the time and duration of the assembly, and the number of participants.

Article 16(1) provides that the competent authorities may prohibit a public assembly if they consider that it poses a threat to public order, public health or safety, national security or the prevention of crime.

Article 18(1) provides for penalties for organisers and participants in unauthorised assemblies. The penalties include fines and administrative detention

...

...
At around 12:00, the protesters began to march towards the bridge. The police blocked their way and a violent confrontation ensued. The protesters threw stones, bottles, and other objects at the police, while the police used water cannons, rubber bullets, and batons to disperse the crowd.
...
The protesters had been informed that they would be allowed to enter the square only after 12:00, when the rally was scheduled to begin. However, the police prevented them from entering the square before that time, and did not allow them to carry any flags, banners, or other items, except for placards. The police also closed the bridge to all traffic, including pedestrian traffic, without informing the protesters of this decision. These actions, which were not taken in accordance with the procedures that had been followed for the two previous rallies on Bolotnaya Square, created a tense and volatile situation, which ultimately led to the violent confrontation between the police and the protesters.

## 2. The case in the European Court of Human Rights

The applicant, Mr. Gennady Yevdokimov, lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights on 12 December 2005. He complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention that the Russian courts had failed to provide him with an effective remedy in respect of the violation of his property rights, and under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 that the Russian authorities had interfered with the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions without just satisfaction.

The application was allocated to the Third Section of the Court. On 23 March 2006, the Court declared the application admissible in respect of both complaints.

The Court’s assessment of the facts

The Court noted that the applicant had purchased the land in question in 1995, and that, in the following years, the authorities had taken steps to protect the Golden Horn Bay area from further development. In particular, in 1998, the Primorskiy regional authorities had adopted a resolution establishing a water protection zone in the area, and, in 2000, the Vladivostok Administration had adopted a town planning scheme which restricted construction activities in the zone.

The Court further noted that, in 2003, the applicant had been informed that the hotel complex was to be built on the land in question. He had then challenged the decision in the domestic courts, but, as the Court had found, his actions had been unsuccessful.

The Court also noted that, in 2004, the applicant had applied to the Russian Constitutional Court for a review of the domestic courts’ decisions. However, the Court had found that the applicant had failed to exhaust domestic remedies in respect of the issue of the effectiveness of the Russian courts’ decisions.

The Court’s assessment of the arguments

The applicant argued that the Russian authorities had interfered with the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions without just satisfaction, as the compensation offered to him had been insufficient. He further argued that the Russian courts had failed to provide him with an effective remedy in respect of the violation of his property

The applicant company’s participation in the cartel is also evidenced by the fact that it had a sales representative in the area where the prices were determined and agreed upon in the cartel.
(1275)  The applicant company has not contested its participation in the cartel in the present proceedings. In the statement of defence, it was only stated that the applicant company had been a victim of the cartel, and that it had been forced to comply with the cartel’s price agreements in order to avoid losing its market position and customers.
(1276)  The applicant company’s argument that it was a victim of the cartel is not convincing. The fact that a company is a victim of a cartel does not exempt it from the obligation to pay the fine imposed by the Market Court. In the present case, the applicant company has not demonstrated that it was in any way coerced into participating in the cartel. On the contrary, the evidence shows that the applicant company had a sales representative in the area where the prices were determined and agreed upon in the cartel, and that it participated in the cartel’s meetings and price negotiations. The applicant company’s argument that it was forced to comply with the cartel’s price agreements in order to avoid losing its market position and customers is not supported by the evidence. The evidence shows that the applicant company continued to sell its products at the cartel prices after the cartel had been detected, and that it did not take any measures to terminate its participation in the cartel until it was confronted with the evidence of its participation.
(1277)  The applicant company’s argument that the fine imposed on it is disproportionate is also not convincing. The applicant company has not contested the facts on which the fine was based, and it has not provided any evidence to show that the fine would be disproportionate in the circumstances of the case. The Market Court’s assessment of the fine was based on the applicant company’s turnover in the relevant market, the duration of its participation in the cartel, and the gravity of the infringement. The applicant company’s turnover in the relevant market was approximately EUR 2.

2.  The applicant’s complaints under Articles 8 and 13 of the Convention

2.1.  The applicant complained that the authorities had failed to protect her property rights under Article 8 of the Convention, and that they had violated her right to an effective remedy under Article 13 in that regard.

2.2.  The Court notes that the second applicant has not alleged any violation of her right to respect for her home under Article 8 of the Convention.  She has only complained about the loss of her property, namely the land on which her house was situated.  The Court has previously held that the right to respect for property under Article 8 of the Convention does not extend to the land on which a person’s home is situated only if that land is being effectively used for agricultural or other productive purposes in the context of a continuing agricultural activity (see, for example, the Kopecky and Others v. Slovakia judgment of 27 April 1995, Reports of Judgments and Decisions 77, p. 102, § 41).  In the present case, the second applicant has not submitted any evidence to suggest that the land on which her house was situated was being used for any agricultural or other productive purposes.  Consequently, the Court will not examine the second applicant’s complaint under Article 8 of the Convention.

2.3.  The Court further notes that the second applicant has not alleged any violation of her right to an effective remedy under Article 13 of the Convention in respect of any alleged violation of her right to respect for her property under Article 8 of the Convention.  Consequently, the Court will not examine the second applicant’s complaint under Article 13 of the Convention in that regard.

They further submitted that the lack of an effective remedy had also infringed their right to a fair hearing under Article 6 § 1.
