They argued that the applicants had not shown that they had been unable to appeal to those courts and that the failure to appeal had not been justified.  The Government further submitted that the applicants had not shown that they had been unable to obtain the information they were seeking from the Ministry of Defence, as they had been able to obtain responses from other military authorities.

The applicants submitted that the Military Code did not provide for an appeal against the decision to discharge from military service to the Military Prosecutor or to the military courts.  They argued that the only remedy available to them was to seek a review of the decision by the Ministry of Defence.  They further submitted that they had been unable to obtain the information they were seeking from the Ministry of Defence, as they had been unable to obtain any response from that Ministry.

The Court notes that the Military Code does not provide for an appeal against a decision to discharge from military service to the Military Prosecutor or to the military courts.  It further notes that the applicants have submitted that they were unable to obtain any response from the Ministry of Defence and that they had been unable to obtain the information they were seeking from that Ministry.  The Court therefore finds that the applicants have not had an effective remedy within the meaning of Article 6 § 1.

B.  Relevant domestic and international law

1.  The European Arrest Warrant Framework Decision

19.  The European Arrest Warrant Framework Decision (Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA of 13 June 2002) (“the Framework Decision”) sets out the procedure for the execution of European arrest warrants. Article 1 provides that the Framework Decision is intended to facilitate the execution in the European Union of warrants or orders for the arrest and surrender of persons issued in the context of criminal proceedings.

20.  Article 2 specifies the types of offences for which a European arrest warrant may be issued. The list includes, inter alia, serious crimes, such as murder, manslaughter, attempted murder, grievous bodily harm, robbery, assault, sexual offences, fraud, forgery, and computer-related offences.

21.  Article 3 sets out the conditions for the issuance of a European arrest warrant. It provides that a request for the execution of a European arrest warrant may be made by a judicial authority of the requesting Member State. The request must be accompanied by a document setting out the reasons for the issuance of the warrant and the essential facts of the case, including the nature and maximum penalty for the offence, and the measures for executing the warrant.

30 per cent share of the property of the former Yugoslav People’s Army (JNA) and the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (SFRJ) in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro, as they stood on 21 December 2002, were incompatible with the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro.
The Constitutional Court further stated that the provisions of the Law on the Realisation of the Share of the Property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro, which were in force on 21 December 2002, did not comply with the requirement of proportionality, and that the provisions of the Law on the Realisation of the Share of the Property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro, which were in force on 21 December 2002, did not allow for the full and effective protection of the property rights of the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro.
The Constitutional Court has requested the National Assembly to amend the Law on the Realisation of the Share of the Property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro within thirty days.
The Military Property Agency, as the body responsible for the realisation of the share of the property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro, hereby informs all interested parties that, in accordance with the Constitutional Court’s decision, the realisation of the 30 per cent share of the property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro will be suspended until the National Assembly adopts the necessary amendments to the Law on the Realisation of the Share of the Property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro.”
On 10 January 2003 the National Assembly of the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro adopted the Law on the Realisation of the Share of the Property of the JNA and SFRJ in the Republic of Serbia and Montenegro, which amended the previous law in the light of the Constitutional Court’s judgment. The investigation file contained the statements of the applicants and other witnesses, the medical certificates of their injuries and the results of the autopsies of the bodies found in the garage. [2] The conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh is a complex and long-standing one. It has its roots in the history of the region and the relationship between its Armenian and Azerbaijani populations. The origins of the conflict can be traced back to the late 19th century, when the area was part of the Russian Empire. The population of Nagorno-Karabakh was predominantly Armenian, but it was administratively part of the Azerbaijan province. After the Russian Revolution, the area was part of the Transcaucasian Federation, which included the Armenian SSR, the Azerbaijan SSR and the Georgian SSR. In 1921, Nagorno-Karabakh was transferred to the Azerbaijan SSR.

In 1988, mass protests by Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh led to the demand for unification with the Armenian SSR. This demand was rejected by the Azerbaijani authorities, and clashes between Armenian and Azerbaijani forces began in February 1988. These clashes escalated into a full-scale conflict in 1991, following the collapse of the USSR. The conflict resulted in the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people from both sides, and the establishment of the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic (“the NKR”) by the Armenian forces.

The conflict was resolved by a ceasefire agreement signed on 12 May 1994, which established a line of contact between the Armenian and Azerbaijani forces. The agreement did not resolve the status of Nagorno-Karabakh, and the conflict remains unresolved to this day.

[3] The United Nations Security Council adopted resolution 822 (1993) on 30 April 1993, which called for a complete and immediate ceasefire, the withdrawal of all Armenian forces from the territories occupied since 1991, and the deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force to monitor the ceasefire. The resolution also called for negotiations between the parties to reach a peaceful settlement of the conflict.

4.  The present case concerns the implementation of the travellers’ reception and accommodation programme for the years 2005-2006 and 2007-2008.

A.  The 2005-2006 programme

1.  General background

The 2005-2006 programme, which was adopted on 22 November 2004, was based on a list of 162 sites in the territory of Belgium, including 113 campsites and 49 parking sites. The sites were classified according to the number of places available for travellers, the services provided and the location.

The programme provided for the allocation of a total of 1,148 places, including 1,081 places in campsites and 67 places in parking sites. The allocation of places was based on a formula which took into account the population of the communes concerned, the number of travellers registered in those communes and the number of places already allocated to those communes in the previous programmes.

The programme provided for a budget of BEL 3,300,000 (approximately EUR 816,000) for the years 2005-2006.

1.  Admissibility of the complaint under Article 31

The Court notes that this complaint is not manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 § 3 of the Convention. It further notes that it is not inadmissible on any other grounds. It must therefore be declared admissible.

B.  Merits

1.  Alleged failure to examine the application for asylum in an effective and timely manner (Article 31)

The Court has found a violation of Article 31 in a number of cases where applicants have been detained for prolonged periods without their applications for asylum being examined (see, for example, M.S.S. v. In the present case, the applicant arrived in Greece on 23 November 2004. He was detained on 24 November 2004 and was not released until 23 March 2005. 2.  The prefect’s decision no. 9468/1985

2.1.  The legislative background

The 1982 Constitution, which entered into force on 18 November 1982, provides in Article 43(1) that “the State shall take the necessary measures for the protection of nature and natural resources, and for the preservation of historical and cultural sites and monuments”. Article 24(1) provides that “everyone has the right to live in a healthy and clean environment”.

The 1985 Law on Planning and Building Regulations (no. 2566) was adopted on 15 May 1985 and entered into force on 18 May 1985. It regulates the procedures for the preparation and implementation of town planning schemes and building regulations. It provides in Article 20(1) that the prefect may, in accordance with the provisions of the law, approve a town planning scheme for a settlement or for part of a settlement. The scheme must be prepared by the local authorities and must include, inter alia, the boundaries of the settlement and the zoning plan. Article 20(2) provides that the prefect may, on the proposal of the local authorities, approve a building permit for a construction project within the boundaries of a settlement or for part of a settlement.

The 1985 Law on the Protection of Cultural and Natural Heritage (no. 2861) was adopted on 24 April 1985 and entered into force on 15 May 1985. It provides in Article 1(1) that the State shall take the necessary measures for the protection and preservation of cultural and natural heritage. Article 2 provides that “the natural heritage is the natural environment, including natural habitats and ecosystems, and natural resources, such as water, forests, wetlands, minerals and fossils”. Article 3 provides that “the State shall take the necessary measures for the protection and preservation of the natural heritage, in accordance with the provisions of the law”.

In the light of the above, the European Commission on Human Rights has concluded that the use of Dworkin's book in the trial of the Chairwoman of the regional Commission for Human Rights in Chelyabinsk, and the constant reference to it by the latter as a reliable source, could not but have had a chilling effect on the freedom of conscience and religion of the Jehovah's Witnesses.

The European Commission on Human Rights further notes that the authorities' conduct towards the Jehovah's Witnesses, as reflected in the case file, appears to be based on a generalised stereotype of the Jehovah's Witnesses as a destructive sect, and on the assumption that their beliefs are false. This approach is incompatible with the provisions of Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which protects freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

The European Commission on Human Rights also notes that the use of Dworkin's book in the trial of the Chairwoman of the regional Commission for Human Rights in Chelyabinsk and the reference to it by her as a reliable source, constituted a violation of the right to a fair trial, as enshrined in Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights. The use of such a source, which was not subject to any form of scrutiny or verification, was not in conformity with the requirements of Article 6(3)(d) of the Convention, which provides that 'everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be entitled to have the evidence presented against him or her examined and assessed in public in the presence of the parties or their representatives'.

The European Commission on Human Rights therefore concludes that the conduct of the authorities towards the Jehovah's Witnesses, as reflected in the case file, constituted a violation of Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which protects freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and of Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantees the right to a fair trial.

The European Commission on Human Rights recommends that the Russian authorities take appropriate measures to ensure that in future cases concerning the freedom of conscience and religion, the authorities refrain from using such material as Dworkin's book, which has been shown to contain unfounded and discriminatory statements about religious

The olive grove was managed by the ‘Prosphigika’ Grove Administration, which was responsible for the cultivation, harvesting, and marketing of the olive oil produced. The Administration was financed by the State and the olive oil produced was sold to the Greek State Monopoly Organization (Ε.Ο.Π.) at a fixed price.

The refugees were required to work in the olive grove for a minimum of 150 days per year and were paid a daily wage. The olive oil produced was used to meet their basic needs and the surplus was sold to the State Monopoly Organization.

The refugees were housed in temporary barracks, which were later replaced by permanent houses. They were also provided with agricultural tools, seeds, and fertilizers.

The ‘Prosphigika’ Grove was a great success, and by 1930 it had become self-sufficient and was even able to export olive oil to other countries. The refugees were able to improve their living conditions and become self-sufficient farmers.

The ‘Prosphigika’ Grove was an important part of the Greek government’s policy to resettle refugees from Asia Minor after the population exchange between Greece and Turkey in 1923. It provided a means for refugees to become self-sufficient farmers and contribute to the Greek economy.

The ‘Prosphigika’ Grove was also an important symbol of the Greek government’s commitment to helping refugees rebuild their lives after the traumatic experience of displacement. It demonstrated that the Greek State was willing to invest in the future of its refugees and provide them with the tools and resources they needed to become productive members of society.

Today, the ‘Prosphigika’ Grove is still in operation and is managed by the Hellenic Agricultural Organization ‘Demeter’. It continues to produce high-quality olive oil and is an important source of income for the local community. It is also an important reminder of the history of the refugee settlement

2.  The parties’ submissions

2.1  The applicant, Draupner, argues that the seizure of the hard disk drive and the USB memory stick was unlawful as it was not based on a warrant issued by a court and that the seizure was disproportionate as the material was not necessary for the conduct of the investigation.

2.2  The respondent Government submit that the seizure of the hard disk drive and the USB memory stick was lawful as it was carried out on the basis of a decision by the Tax Agency, which was authorised to conduct searches and seizures under the Tax Procedure Act, and that the seizure was proportionate as the material seized was necessary for the conduct of the investigation.

3.  The Court’s assessment

3.1  The Court recalls that the right to respect for private and family life, as enshrined in Article 8 of the Convention, includes the right to the protection of personal data (see, inter alia, Malone v. the United Kingdom, 2 August 1984, § 66, Series A no. 82; and Axel Springer AG and others v. Germany, no. 39954/08, § 57, 25 February 2014).

3.2  The Court further recalls that the seizure of documents and data from a person’s premises constitutes a particularly serious interference with the right to respect for private life and the right to the protection of personal data (see, inter alia, Axel Springer AG and others, cited above, § 61).

3.3  In the present case, the seizure of the hard disk drive and the USB memory stick from Draupner’s business premises on 11 May 2010 constituted an interference with Draupner’s right to respect for private life and the right to the protection of personal data.

3.4  The Court reiterates that the Contracting States have a wide margin of appreciation in deciding on the measures to be taken for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences, and that this margin is particularly wide in the area of

2.1.  The applicant’s statement of 13 May 2002

On 13 May 2002 the applicant gave a statement to the investigators. She stated that on 23 April 2002 at around 11 a.m. she had gone to the market with her husband and their three children, who were aged between three and six years old. After they had finished shopping, they had left the market and had been walking towards their car. They had been stopped by a man in a white car, who had asked them for their identity cards. The applicant had shown him her identity card and had asked her husband to do the same. The man had then asked them to get into the car. The applicant had refused, but her husband had got into the car. The man had then forced her into the car and had driven them to a deserted area. She had not been able to see where they had been taken. There she had been beaten by two men and had been forced to undress. She had then been raped by three men. She had been unable to recognise them, as they had been wearing masks. After the rape she had been left in the forest and had managed to return home at around 11 p.m. She had been unable to tell her children what had happened to her.

She had reported the incident to the police on 24 April 2002. She had been taken to the police station, where she had been questioned by the investigators. She had not been able to identify her attackers. She had been taken to the hospital for a medical examination. She had not been able to recognise the doctor, as he had been wearing a mask. She had not been able to tell her children about the incident, as they had been too frightened.

The Greek State has appealed against those judgments.  The plots in question are located in the area of the Veikou Estate which was not subject to the 1963 expropriation order.

28.  In the present case the applicant is seeking to establish that the Greek State is in breach of its obligations under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention to maintain the status quo in respect of the Veikou Estate.  She argues that the State has unlawfully transferred the ownership of parts of the Estate to private individuals and that the State’s failure to take measures to prevent such transfers has resulted in the loss of a significant part of the Estate.

29.  The applicant’s argument is based on the fact that the Greek State had not taken measures to prevent the sale of the plots in question and that those sales were in breach of the provisions of the law on the expropriation of immovable property.  She submits that the Greek State’s failure to comply with its obligations under that law constitutes a breach of its positive obligations under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.  She further submits that the Greek State’s failure to take measures to prevent the sale of the plots in question has resulted in a loss of a significant part of the Veikou Estate.

30.  The Court notes that the applicant’s argument is based on the assumption that the Greek State had a positive obligation under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to prevent the sale of the plots in question.  It is not in dispute that the Greek State failed to comply with the provisions of the law on the expropriation of immovable property in respect of those plots.  The applicant argues that the State’s failure to comply with that law constituted a breach of its positive obligations under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.

The applicant complained to the European Commission of Human Rights that the decision on his dismissal had been taken in his absence, that the court had not examined the substance of the case and that the decision had been based on false evidence.

On 16 December 1998 the Commission declared the application inadmissible as being an abuse of the right of petition, in particular, because the applicant had not exhausted domestic remedies.

The applicant submitted that the decision on his dismissal had been taken in his absence and that the domestic courts had not examined the substance of the case. He also argued that the decision had been based on false evidence.

The Court notes that the applicant did not exhaust domestic remedies in respect of the alleged violation of his right to a fair trial. In particular, he did not appeal to the Supreme Court against the judgment of the Lviv Regional Court.

The Court reiterates that, according to Article 35 § 1 of the Convention, the Court may only deal with applications which are admissible in accordance with Article 35. In the present case, the applicant did not exhaust domestic remedies, and the application is therefore inadmissible under Article 35 § 1 (a).

For these reasons, the Court, unanimously,

DECLARES THE APPLICATION INADMISSIBLE.

8.  The Carinthian Hospital Act regulates the organisation, financing and operation of the Carinthian hospitals. The Act provides for the establishment of the KABEG, the tasks and responsibilities of the KABEG and the hospitals, and the financing of the hospitals. The Act also contains provisions on the organisation of the hospitals, the provision of healthcare services, the rights and obligations of the patients and the employees, and the quality management of the hospitals.

9.  The Carinthian Hospital Financing Act regulates the financing of the hospitals. It provides for the financing of the hospitals by the Carinthian Regional Government and the municipalities, as well as by the Federal Government. The Act also contains provisions on the calculation of the hospital budgets, the allocation of the hospital budgets and the reimbursement of the hospitals for the provision of healthcare services.

10.  The Carinthian Regional Government and the municipalities are the main financial contributors to the hospitals. The Federal Government contributes to the financing of the hospitals through the Federal Health Insurance Fund (Bundesgesundheitsversicherungsfonds – hereinafter “the G-BA”). The G-BA reimburses the hospitals for the provision of healthcare services to patients insured under the statutory health insurance scheme.

11.  The KABEG is responsible for the management of the hospitals and for the provision of healthcare services. The KABEG is governed by a supervisory board (Aufsichtsrat) and a management board (Vorstand). The supervisory board is composed of representatives of the Carinthian Regional Government, the municipalities and the employees. The management board is responsible for the day-to-day management of the KABEG and for the provision of healthcare services.

Comment:

The judgment is of interest for its analysis of the defendants’ duty to prevent floods and the extent to which that duty can be held to apply to unauthorised constructions and debris in the floodplain. The judgment suggests that, in the absence of any specific statutory provision, a duty to prevent floods does not extend to unauthorised constructions or debris in the floodplain. The Court appears to have taken the view that the duty to prevent floods is a duty owed to the public at large, and that it is not the defendants’ responsibility to prevent floods caused by unauthorised constructions or debris. The Court’s approach is consistent with the Russian Civil Code, which imposes a duty on the State to protect citizens from natural disasters, but does not impose any corresponding duty on private parties. The judgment is also consistent with the Russian Supreme Court’s decision in case No. 14-113-01 of 25 October 2001, in which the Supreme Court held that the State is not liable for damage caused by floods if the flood was not caused by any action or omission on the part of the State.

The judgment is also of interest for its analysis of the claimants’ argument that the defendants should be held liable for the destructive consequences of the evacuation of water from the Pionerskoye reservoir. The Court therefore rejected the claimants’ argument that the defendants should be held liable for the destructive consequences of the evacuation of water from the reservoir. The applicant submitted that the decision to deprive him of his liberty was not taken in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law. He argued that he had been held in the social care home for over six months without a court order and that he had not been informed of his right to appeal against the decision to deprive him of his liberty. He further argued that he had been held in the social care home despite the fact that he had been diagnosed as being capable of living independently.

The Court found that there had been a violation of Article 5(1) of the Convention. It noted that the applicant had been deprived of his liberty for over six months without a court order and that the domestic authorities had failed to provide any explanation for the absence of such an order. The Court also noted that the applicant had been held in the social care home despite having been diagnosed as being capable of living independently.

The Court further found that there had been a violation of Article 5(4) of the Convention. It noted that the applicant had not been informed of his right to appeal against the decision to deprive him of his liberty and that there had been no effective remedy available to him to challenge the lawfulness of his detention.

The Court awarded the applicant damages of €10,000 under Article 41 of the Convention.

### Application no. 22335/12, Kovács v. Hungary

The applicant, a Hungarian national, was detained in a social care home for persons with mental disorders for over six months without a court order. He complained that his detention was in breach of Article 5(1) of the European Convention on Human Rights.

The Court found that there had been a violation of Article 5(1) of the Convention. It noted that the applicant had been detained for over six months without a court order and that there had been no adequate and effective review of the lawfulness of his detention.

The Court further found that there had been a violation of Article 5(4) of the Convention. It noted that the applicant had not been informed of his right to appeal against the decision to deprive him of his liberty and that there had been no effective remedy available to him to challenge the lawfulness of his detention.

The Court awarded the applicant damages of €5,0

The ROVD had considered that the applicant’s injury had been caused by stray bullets and that the applicant had not been the target of the shooting. The ROVD had concluded that the applicant had not been the victim of a crime and that there was no reason to institute criminal proceedings.

The applicant complained under Article 3 of the Convention about the failure to institute criminal proceedings in respect of his injury. He also complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention about the lack of an effective remedy in respect of that failure.

The Court noted that the applicant had not been the victim of an intentional attack and that the authorities had conducted an investigation into the circumstances of the incident. It considered that the failure to institute criminal proceedings in respect of the applicant’s injury did not amount to a violation of Article 3 of the Convention.

As to the applicant’s complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, the Court noted that the ROVD had conducted an investigation and had taken a decision not to institute criminal proceedings. The applicant had been able to challenge that decision before the Prosecutor General and the court. The Court considered that the applicant had had an effective remedy available to him under domestic law.

Accordingly, the Court dismissed the applicant’s complaints under Articles 3 and 6 § 1 of the Convention.

On 23 January, the authorities detained and later sentenced 15 members of the opposition Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan (DVK) party, who were planning to hold a peaceful protest in Almaty against the government’s decision to hold the OSCE summit in Astana. The charges against them included organizing an unsanctioned protest and inciting social discord. Some of them were released on bail, but others remained in detention for several weeks.
On 16 March, a peaceful protest against the construction of a new mosque in the village of Shymkent was dispersed by police using excessive force, including teargas, water cannons and batons. More than 30 people were reported to have been injured.
On 23 March, at least 1,000 people gathered in Almaty to mark the 15th anniversary of the Imanovskoe massacre, in which at least 167 people were killed during protests against the closure of an oil refinery in Zhanaozen in December 1991. The authorities denied permission for the protest to take place and used excessive force to disperse it, resulting in injuries to several dozen people.
On 15 April, the authorities detained 25 members of the opposition Alga party, including its leader, Vladimir Kozlov, who was later charged with inciting social discord and calling for the violent overthrow of the government. Kozlov was sentenced to seven and a half years’ imprisonment in December.

“The Mountain Institute is continuing to provide assistance in the aftermath of the disaster. In particular, we are working to help the local population rebuild their homes and restore their livelihoods. We are also conducting research to better understand the causes of the disaster and to develop measures to prevent similar disasters in the future.”

Source: Mountain Institute, 1999.

The Mountain Institute has also provided assistance in the aftermath of other natural disasters in the region, including the 1997 floods in Chechnya and the 1998 earthquake in Armenia.

In addition to its disaster response work, the Mountain Institute is involved in a range of other activities aimed at promoting sustainable development in the mountain regions of the former Soviet Union. These activities include:

- Supporting the development of community-based tourism initiatives in the Caucasus and Central Asia.
- Providing training and education programs for mountain communities in areas such as sustainable agriculture, renewable energy, and small business development.
- Conducting research on the impacts of climate change on mountain ecosystems and communities, and developing strategies to adapt to these changes.
- Advocating for the rights of mountain communities and promoting their participation in decision-making processes related to their lands and resources.

Overall, the Mountain Institute's work in the mountain regions of the former Soviet Union reflects a commitment to promoting sustainable development and reducing the risks of natural disasters through a combination of research, education, and practical assistance.

The applicant was subsequently suspended from practice for a period of six months.

The applicant complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention that he had been deprived of his right to a fair trial because he had been unable to defend his clients effectively during the trial due to the fact that he had been suspended from practice during the proceedings. He also complained under Article 13 of the Convention that there had been no effective remedy available to him in respect of the alleged violation of his right to a fair trial.

The Court reiterated that Article 6 § 1 of the Convention guaranteed the right to a fair trial, and that the effective conduct of a defendant’s defence was an essential aspect of that right. The Court further reiterated that the Convention did not require the presence of a lawyer at every stage of the proceedings, but that it did require that the defendant be afforded a reasonable opportunity to be heard in his defence in person or through a lawyer of his own choosing. The Court noted that the applicant had been present at the trial, but that he had been unable to defend his clients effectively because he had been suspended from practice at the time of the hearing. The Court further noted that the applicant had not been able to justify his absence from the hearing and that the court had been unable to accept the substitute defence counsel. The Court considered that the applicant had been unable to defend his clients effectively during the trial, which had constituted a violation of his clients’ right to a fair trial under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.

The Court further noted that the applicant had not exhausted all available domestic remedies, as he had not appealed against the decision suspending him from practice. The Court therefore dismissed the application as being inadmissible under Article 35 § 1 of the Convention.

The applicant complained to the Constitutional Court that the State had violated her right to respect for her private and family life, as guaranteed by Article 8 of the Convention, and her right to an effective remedy, as guaranteed by Article 13 of the Convention.

The Constitutional Court found that the applicant's complaints were well founded. The State had failed to conduct an effective investigation into her son's disappearance and had not provided her with any information about the progress of the investigation. The Constitutional Court held that the State's actions had caused the applicant significant distress and anxiety, and that her right to respect for her private and family life had been violated. The Constitutional Court also found that the applicant had been denied an effective remedy as she had not been able to obtain any information about the investigation, and that her complaints to the authorities had not been dealt with in an effective manner.

The Constitutional Court ordered the authorities to conduct an effective investigation into the applicant's son's disappearance and to inform the applicant about the progress of the investigation. The Constitutional Court also ordered the authorities to pay the applicant 3,000 HRK in non-pecuniary damages.

The Constitutional Court's decision was final and binding.

The applicant complained to the European Court of Human Rights that there had been a violation of Article 8 and Article 13 of the Convention.

The European Court of Human Rights noted that the investigation into the applicant's son's disappearance had been ongoing for several years and that the applicant had received very little information about the progress of the investigation. The European Court of Human Rights held that the State had failed to conduct an effective investigation into the applicant's son's disappearance and had not provided the applicant with any information about the investigation, in violation of Article 8 of the Convention. The European Court of Human Rights also found that the applicant had been denied an effective remedy as she had not been able to obtain any information about the investigation, in violation of Article 13 of the Convention.

In 1997, the Batalova Vodenitsa residents were forcibly evicted from their homes. The eviction was accompanied by violence, intimidation, and destruction of property. The evicted families were given only a few days to leave their homes and were not offered alternative housing. The authorities promised to provide housing for the evicted families, but to date this has not been done.

The eviction was accompanied by a campaign of harassment and intimidation against the residents. The police and the special riot police unit, the Mobila Brannia, were involved in the eviction. The authorities used excessive force against the residents, who resisted the eviction by blocking the roads and setting up barricades. The police and the special riot police unit used teargas, rubber bullets, and batons against the residents.

The authorities also prevented the residents from leaving the area to seek shelter elsewhere. The police blocked the roads leading out of the area and prevented the residents from leaving with their belongings. The authorities also confiscated the residents’ identity documents, making it difficult for them to obtain alternative housing or to register their children in school.

The authorities also destroyed the residents’ property during the eviction. The homes were bulldozed and the contents were either destroyed or taken away. The residents were not given any compensation for the destruction of their property.

The eviction was carried out in violation of the residents’ right to housing and their right to peaceful assembly. The authorities did not provide the residents with adequate notice of the eviction or offer them alternative housing. The use of excessive force against the residents during the eviction was also a violation of their right to personal security.

The eviction of the Batalova Vodenitsa residents was part of a larger campaign by the authorities to evict Roma and other minority groups from their homes in Bulgaria. The campaign was accompanied by widespread discrimination and violence against Roma and other minorities. The authorities used the pretext of urban renewal and the need to improve living conditions to justify the evictions, but in reality the evictions were motivated by discrimination and a desire to remove Roma and other minorities from certain areas.

The eviction of the Batalova Vodenitsa residents was also part of a larger pattern of human rights violations against Roma and other minorities in Bulgaria. The

[12] The Supreme Court also noted that the 1963 diver had not been a trespasser on the State's land, but rather a lawful occupant, as he had been employed by the State as a diver.  In this regard, the Supreme Court cited the following passage from the judgment of the House of Lords in _Donoghue v Stevenson_ (1932) 56 SCR 586 at 594:

"[I]t is a fundamental principle that the occupier of land owes a duty to persons entering thereon by lawful means to keep the premises reasonably safe for them.  This duty is owed not only to those whom he invites upon the premises, but also to those who are lawfully there without his invitation.  The duty is not owed to trespassers."

[13] The Supreme Court further noted that the State had not only owed a duty of care to the 1963 diver, but had also breached that duty.  The State had been aware of the risk posed by the presence of the abandoned vessel, but had failed to take any steps to remove it or to warn the diver of its presence.  The Supreme Court found that the State's failure to take such steps constituted a breach of its duty of care to the 1963 diver.

[14] In considering whether the State could be held liable on the basis of the general principle of negligence, the Supreme Court noted that the State had owed a duty of care to the 1963 diver, and that it had breached that duty by failing to take reasonable steps to protect him from the risk posed by the abandoned vessel.  The Supreme Court further noted that the State's breach of duty had been the cause of the 1963 diver's injuries.

label: South Darfur
output: Minnesota, New Jersey, and New York have laws against the practice. In 2013 the American Academy of Pediatrics issued a statement opposing FGM/C, but it does not have the force of law. The U.S. government considers FGM/C a violation of the rights of children under the Convention on the Rights of the Child and a form of gender-based violence under the Violence Against Women Act. FGM/C is not widespread in the United States, but there are believed to be between 165,000 and 513,000 women and girls in the United States who have undergone the procedure or are at risk. Many are immigrants from countries where FGM/C is practiced. The majority of these women and girls are from Africa, but there are also significant numbers from the Middle East and Asia. The practice is concentrated in urban areas, particularly in New York City, Detroit, and Minneapolis. There are also reports of FGM/C among immigrant communities in California, Illinois, Maryland, New Jersey, Texas, and Virginia. FGM/C is usually performed by traditional practitioners, who may travel from country to country to perform the procedure. In 2013 the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that 21 percent of girls and women between the ages of 15 and 49 who were born in Africa and had immigrated to the United States had undergone FGM/C. The CDC also reported that 1.8 percent of girls and women from Asia and 0.6 percent of those from the Middle East had undergone FGM/C. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 14 percent of women and girls between the ages of 15 and 49 in the United States who were born in countries where FGM/C is practiced have undergone the procedure. The majority of FGM/C cases in the United States involve girls under the age of 18. The most common type of FGM/C practiced in the United States is Type I, or clitoridectomy, in which the clitoral hood is removed and the clitoris may be cut. The least common type, Type III, or infibulation, in which the external genitalia are sewn together, has been reported in the United States but is rare.

The court found that the applicant had not shown that the disclosure of the fact that he had been an agent of the StB had caused him any harm. The court further considered that the applicant had not shown that the disclosure of the fact that he had been an agent of the StB had affected his professional reputation or his business activities. The court therefore dismissed the applicant’s claim for damages.
The applicant appealed to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court upheld the judgment of the Regional Court.

3.  The Roma are traditionally a nomadic people, and they have been subjected to discrimination and persecution throughout history.  The Roma have been described as a marginalized, stigmatized, and socially excluded minority.  They have faced numerous challenges, such as social exclusion, poverty, unemployment, lack of access to education, health care, and housing, and discrimination in various spheres of life.

4.  The Roma have been subjected to forced assimilation policies, including forced sterilization, forced labor, and forced settlement.  In the 19th and 20th centuries, the Roma were subjected to mass expulsions and deportations from various European countries.  In the 1940s, during the Second World War, the Roma were targeted for extermination by the Nazi regime, and hundreds of thousands of Roma were killed.

5.  In recent years, there have been reports of discrimination and violence against the Roma in various European countries, including Hungary.  According to a report by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), Roma children in Hungary face discrimination in education, and Roma families often live in poverty and lack access to basic services.  The FRA report also notes that Roma women are subjected to forced sterilization, and that Roma men are subjected to discrimination in the labor market.

6.  In 2010, the Hungarian government adopted a new constitution, which included provisions that were criticized for being discriminatory towards the Roma. "1.  Everyone's right to life shall be protected by law.  No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in the execution of a sentence of a court following his conviction of a criminal offence involving intentional lethal or grievous bodily harm, or of the death penalty imposed for military reasons in pursuance of a sentence passed following a fair trial.

2.  Deprivation of life shall not be regarded as inflicted in contravention of this Article when it results from the use of force which is no more than absolutely necessary:

(a)  in defence of any person from unlawful violence;

(b)  in order to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent the escape of a person lawfully detained;

(c)  in action lawfully taken for the purpose of quelling a riot or insurrection.

3.  Nothing in this Article shall authorise any restrictions on caring for the needs of the person in custody.

4.  In times of war or other public emergency threatening the life of the nation any derogation from Article 2, paragraph 1, is justifiable provided it is in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 2 and subject to such safeguards as the Contracting States may in each case prescribe in their legislation. The Court observes that the Covenant does not contain any provision defining the scope of its application territorially. However, the general principles of international law, including the principle of effectiveness, require that a treaty be interpreted in good faith and in a manner that enables it to be effectively implemented. The Court has consistently held that the application of a treaty is not confined to the territory of the parties to the treaty when the treaty itself, or the context in which it is to be applied, or the objectives it pursues, so indicate ...
The Court considers that the Covenant, as an instrument intended to ensure the effective implementation of the fundamental human rights enshrined in it, cannot be understood as confined to the territory of the parties to the Covenant. It is also clear from the object and purpose of the Covenant that it applies to all persons subject to the jurisdiction of a State Party, regardless of their nationality or the territory on which they find themselves. The Court reaffirms that the protection of the Covenant extends to all acts of States organs, including military forces.
The Court further considers that the fact that the Covenant does not contain any provision expressly defining its territorial scope is not a reason for denying its application to the occupied territories. In this respect, the Court recalls that the Covenant was adopted in 1966, when the question of the application of international human rights law to the occupied territories was not yet a matter of controversy. The Court also recalls that, at that time, there was no clear consensus in international law as to the applicability of human rights treaties to the occupied territories.
The Court observes that the position taken by Israel in relation to the applicability of the Covenant to the occupied territories has been challenged by the Human Rights Committee and other international bodies, and that Israel has not replied to their observations. The Court further observes that Israel has not contested the applicability of the Covenant to the occupied territories in the present case. In these circumstances, the Court finds that the Covenant applies to the occupied territories, including to the residents thereof, and that Israel, as the occupying power, is bound to ensure the respect of the

“The main goal of Hizb ut Tahrir is to establish a caliphate (Islamic state) under Islamic law (Sharia) in the entire Islamic world, including the Muslim parts of Russia and China. This goal is to be achieved through the ‘da’wa’ (proselytizing) of Muslims and by the establishment of an Islamic government through elections. The movement does not call for violence against non-Muslims, but for a peaceful takeover of power through the ballot box.
“The movement has a hierarchical structure, with a ‘Khilafah’ (caliph) at the top, who is elected by the ‘Shura’ (consultative council) and who is the religious and political leader of the entire movement. The Shura is composed of members of the ‘Majlis al Shura al A’la’ (highest consultative council) and of the ‘Majlis al Shura al Kubra’ (great consultative council). The latter is the highest representative body of the movement, which meets every three years to discuss the political situation and to elect the members of the Shura. Article 125 § 1 of the Russian Federation Code of Criminal Procedure provides:

“The investigator may take the following measures to ensure the appearance of the accused at the trial:
(a)  to warn the accused of the necessity to appear at the trial and to take his or her signature on a promise to appear;
(b)  to detain the accused;
(c)  to apply other measures, stipulated by this Code and other legislation of the Russian Federation.”

Article 125 § 2 of the Russian Federation Code of Criminal Procedure provides:

“The investigator may detain the accused if there are grounds to believe that he or she may evade criminal prosecution, or if the circumstances of the case or the nature of the offence committed warrant the application of such a measure. The investigator shall apply to the court for a decision on detention within 24 hours after the detention.”

Article 125 § 3 of the Russian Federation Code of Criminal Procedure provides:

“The court shall make a decision on detention if there are grounds to believe that the accused may evade criminal prosecution or if the circumstances of the case or the nature of the offence committed warrant the application of such a measure. The term of detention shall not exceed two months, unless otherwise provided by this Code or other legislation of the Russian Federation. The court shall hear the application of the investigator in camera. The accused shall be informed of the decision and the grounds for it. The decision on detention shall be served on the accused immediately after its adoption.”

Article 125 § 4 of the Russian Federation Code of Criminal Procedure provides:

“The term of detention may be extended by the investigator for a period not exceeding thirty days if there are grounds to believe that the accused may evade criminal prosecution. The investigator shall apply to the court for a decision on the extension of the term of detention within twenty-four hours before the expiry of the term of detention. On 17 July 2002 the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation lodged a cassation appeal against the judgment. The cassation appeal was based on the ground that the judgment had been delivered in violation of the applicant's right to a fair trial, as the court had failed to examine the evidence presented by the Ministry.

On 25 November 2002 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation rejected the cassation appeal.

The applicant complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention that the consolidated police units had remained in occupation of his property despite a judgment ordering their eviction, and that the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation had not taken any steps to ensure the execution of the judgment. He further complained under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 that the Russian authorities had failed to protect his right to peaceful enjoyment of his possessions.

The Court notes that the applicant's complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention is closely linked to his complaint under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1, and that the two complaints must be examined together.

I.  THE GOVERNMENT'S PRELIMINARY OBJECTION

The Government contested the admissibility of the application on the ground that the applicant had not exhausted domestic remedies. They argued that the applicant had not taken any steps to enforce the judgment of 14 February 2001 and that he had not challenged the failure of the Ministry of Internal Affairs to take any measures to ensure the execution of the judgment.

The Government submitted that the applicants had acquired the disputed land in breach of the 1944 expropriation law, which had been enacted in order to ensure the security of the Bulgarian population in the border areas. The Commission found that the applicants had acquired the disputed land from the Bulgarian State in 1963, in accordance with the law in force at the time. It further found that the expropriation of 1944 had been carried out in violation of the 1942 Bulgarian Constitution and that, therefore, the expropriation had been invalid. B.  Relevant domestic law and practice

1.  Criminal Code

Article 126 § 1 provides:

“A person who, acting in concert with other persons, commits a crime against a person’s life, health, freedom or property, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term of between three and twelve years.”

Article 126 § 2 provides:

“A person who commits a crime against a person’s life, health, freedom or property with the use of a weapon, by inflicting particularly grave bodily harm, or by causing a particularly grave consequence, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term of between five and fifteen years.”

Article 126 § 3 provides:

“A person who commits a crime against a person’s life, health, freedom or property by inflicting particularly grave bodily harm, or by causing a particularly grave consequence, with the use of a particularly dangerous weapon, or in a particularly cruel manner, or against a particularly vulnerable person, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term of between ten and twenty years.”

Article 126 § 4 provides:

“A person who commits a crime against a person’s life, health, freedom or property in a group, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term of between five and fifteen years, and the punishment shall be increased by one third if the crime was committed in a particularly cruel manner or against a particularly vulnerable person.”

Article 126 § 5 provides:

“A person who commits a crime against a person’s life, health, freedom or property in a group and in a particularly cruel manner or against a particularly vulnerable person, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term of between ten and twenty-five years.”

Article 126 § 6 provides:

“A person who commits a crime against a person’

This case law highlights the importance of the distinction between discrimination and the application of different legal regimes. The Belgian case law is also in line with the approach taken by the European Court of Human Rights in the case of Schalk and Kopf v Austria, in which the Court held that the denial of recognition of same-sex marriages did not amount to discrimination, as the Austrian legislation did not establish a difference in treatment based on the sexual orientation of the parties, but rather did not recognise a relationship which did not exist under Austrian law. However, in this case, the Court also emphasised that the right to respect for private and family life may require the recognition of same-sex marriages, as the refusal to do so may amount to a violation of this right.

### 1.1.3 The United Kingdom

The United Kingdom's immigration rules have a separate category for refugees. Under the Rules, a person is considered a refugee if he or she is outside the country of nationality and unable or unwilling to return to it because of a well-founded fear of persecution on account of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion. The United Kingdom is a signatory to the 1951 Refugee Convention and the 1967 Protocol, which set out the definition of a refugee.

The United Kingdom's immigration rules also have a category for persons granted humanitarian protection. A person is considered to have been granted humanitarian protection if he or she is outside the country of nationality and unable or unwilling to return to it because of a well-founded fear of serious and individual threat to his or her life or freedom on account of indiscriminate violence, or other circumstances, which have not reached the threshold of persecution.

They contended that the applicant's expulsion had been a proportionate measure necessary in a democratic society for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. The French education system was based on the principle of secularism, which meant that religious symbols could not be worn at school. The wearing of the headscarf was a manifestation of a religious belief and, as such, it was a matter of individual freedom. A BIRD IN THE HAND

A man was brought into the courtroom. He was wearing a black suit and a tie. He was accompanied by a woman, a blonde with a beautiful figure. The woman was wearing a red dress and a hat. The man looked at her with adoring eyes. The woman was holding a bird in her hands. It was a sparrow. The man was trembling with emotion. The woman was stroking the bird.
The judge asked: ‘What is the reason for your appearance in court today?’
The man replied: ‘Your Honour, I have been accused of stealing a sparrow.’
The judge: ‘And who is the owner of the sparrow?’
The woman: ‘I am the owner, Your Honour.’
The judge: ‘Why did you bring the sparrow to court?’
The woman: ‘My dear husband has been stealing sparrows from me for a long time. He took this one today. I decided to put an end to it.’
The judge: ‘Did you catch him red-handed?’
The woman: ‘Yes, Your Honour. I caught him with this sparrow in his hands.’
The judge: ‘Did you report the theft to the police?’
The woman: ‘No, Your Honour. I decided to deal with it myself.’
The judge: ‘Why did you bring the sparrow to court?’
The man: ‘Your Honour, I am a bird lover. I like to catch sparrows and keep them in a cage. I have a whole collection of them. I didn’t steal this one. I bought it from a man at the market.’
The judge: ‘Where did you buy it?’
The man: ‘At the bird market, Your Honour.’
The judge: ‘Do you have a receipt?’
The man: ‘No, Your Honour. I didn’t ask for one.’
The judge: ‘Did you see the seller?’
The man: ‘Yes, Your Honour. He was a tall man with a beard.’
The judge: ‘Do you know his name?’
The man: ‘No, Your Honour. I didn’t ask him.’

In 1993 he was arrested for possession of a weapon and sentenced to a term of imprisonment. After serving part of his sentence, he was released on parole on 11 February 1994.

The police team arrived at the flat and knocked on the door. They identified themselves as police officers and asked Mr Taşkın Usta to open the door. The applicants’ daughter opened the door and allowed the police team to enter. Mr Taşkın Usta was in the living room of the flat. He was unarmed. He did not resist arrest.

The police team arrested Mr Taşkın Usta and searched the flat. They found no weapons. The applicants and their daughter were taken to the police station for questioning.

The arrests of independent Muslims followed a pattern. The police would raid a home, arrest the men present, and take the women and children to a local police station. The women and children were usually released after a few hours, but the men were taken to the local police station for interrogation, and then to the National Security Service (SNB) for further interrogation. The interrogations were often violent and included beatings, threats, and demands for confessions. The men were then taken to court, where they were tried in closed trials, and sentenced to prison terms ranging from three to fifteen years.
The charges against the independent Muslims were usually based on Article 154, Part 1 of the Criminal Code, which prohibits the organization of, or participation in, religious organizations not registered with the government. Article 154, Part 2, which prohibits the dissemination of religious materials not registered with the government, was also used. The men were charged with having membership in Hizb ut-Tahrir, and with disseminating its literature. In many cases, the men were charged with having committed “extremist acts” - such as attending a mosque without a state-issued permit, or having a copy of the Koran in their possession - that were not specified in the Criminal Code.
The trials of the independent Muslims were held in closed sessions, and the defendants were not allowed to have legal representation. The trials were often conducted in a summary fashion, with the defendants being sentenced on the same day they were tried. The trials were often conducted in violation of the Criminal Procedure Code, which requires that the defendants be informed of the charges against them, be allowed to confront witnesses, and be allowed to present evidence on their own behalf. The trials were also conducted in violation of the Constitution, which guarantees the right to a fair trial.

### 3.3.3.2.2.2.3. Proportionality of the detention in the context of the asylum procedure

In the context of asylum procedures, the proportionality of detention has been assessed in relation to the duration of the procedure. The ECtHR has found that the detention of an asylum seeker for a period of up to six months is generally proportionate, given the complexity of the asylum procedure and the need to ensure effective implementation of expulsion measures. However, the Court has also found that detention for longer periods may be considered disproportionate, depending on the circumstances of the case. In the case of _Mamatkulov v. Austria_, the ECtHR found that the detention of an asylum seeker for 13 months was disproportionate, since the asylum procedure had not yet been completed and the applicant had not been given any indication of when a decision would be made on his asylum application. The Court noted that the detention had become arbitrary and that the applicant's mental and physical health had deteriorated during his detention.

In the case of _S.S. v. Austria_, the ECtHR found that the detention of an asylum seeker for 14 months was proportionate, given that the applicant had failed to cooperate with the asylum authorities and had refused to disclose his identity

2. The situation in Transdniestria from 1992 to 1994

The situation in Transdniestria remained tense and unstable during the period from 1992 to 1994. The separatist authorities, who had proclaimed the independence of the Transdniestrian Moldovan Republic (TMR) on 2 September 1991, continued to develop their administrative structures, issuing laws and decrees, and establishing a police force, a customs service and a central bank. The TMR also set up a number of ministries, including a Ministry of Defence, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a Ministry of Education. The separatist authorities also took control of the media, establishing their own radio and television stations and newspapers.

The separatist authorities also continued to maintain their military forces, which were largely made up of the former 14th Army. The ROG continued to provide the separatist forces with arms, ammunition and other military equipment, and the Russian military continued to be stationed in Transdniestria.

The Moldovan authorities, for their part, continued to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict. In February 1992 they proposed a plan for a cease-fire and the withdrawal of foreign troops from Transdniestria. The separatist authorities rejected the proposal, and fighting continued.

In July 1992 the Moldovan authorities and the OSCE began negotiations on a cease-fire and the withdrawal of foreign troops from Transdniestria. The negotiations were complicated by the fact that the separatist authorities were not participating in them, and by the continued presence and support of the Russian military.

The situation was exacerbated by the fact that Moldova had no alternative source of gas, and the country was heavily dependent on Russian gas imports. The Russian Government had also imposed a number of conditions on Moldova, including the requirement that it pay for the gas in rubles rather than US dollars. In 2009, Moldova had signed a deal with the European Union to diversify its energy sources by importing gas from Azerbaijan and Romania, but the deal had not yet been implemented.

The gas debt had also been a major source of tension between Moldova and the European Union. The European Union had provided significant financial assistance to Moldova, including a USD 200 million loan in 2009 to help the country meet its energy bills. The European Union had also urged Moldova to diversify its energy sources and reduce its dependence on Russian gas. However, the European Union had not been able to provide Moldova with an alternative source of gas, and the country had remained heavily dependent on Russian imports.

In 2010, the European Union had offered to mediate between Moldova and Russia to find a solution to the gas debt issue. The European Union had proposed that Moldova and Russia enter into a long-term gas supply contract, with the European Union acting as a guarantor. The European Union had also proposed that Russia write off a significant portion of Moldova’s gas debt in exchange for Moldova agreeing to pay the remaining amount in instalments over a number of years. The Russian Government had initially rejected the European Union’s proposal, but had subsequently agreed to negotiate on the issue.

The negotiations between Moldova and Russia had continued throughout 2011, with several deadlines being missed. A.  Alleged violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1

1.  The applicants complain that their possessions were unlawfully taken from them. They argue that the 1993 settlement was valid and that the State was therefore obliged to respect their rights under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.

2.  The Court recalls that Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 provides that everyone has the right to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions. The term “possessions” refers to property as well as to any right or interest which the individual may have in that property. The protection of this provision extends to tangible and intangible property and to property rights as such, whether the latter are registered or not, and to property which may be owned either individually or in common with others (see, among other authorities, the Kraaijenbrink and Others v. the Netherlands judgment of 27 October 1994, Series A no. 296-B, p. 34, § 51).

The application was rejected on the grounds that the applicant association did not meet the statutory requirements for a religious association under the Religious Denominations Act (the “Act”). The rejection was based on the following grounds:

(a) The applicant association did not have a religious doctrine;

(b) The applicant association did not have a religious organisation or religious community in Bulgaria; and

(c) The applicant association did not have a registered office in Bulgaria.

The applicant association lodged an appeal against the decision of the Sofia City Administrative Court, which was dismissed. The applicant association then lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights (the “Court”).

The applicant association argued that the rejection of its application for registration as a religious association violated its freedom of religion under Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Rights (the “Convention”).

The Court noted that the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion is one of the fundamental human rights, which includes freedom to manifest one’s religion in community with others and in public. The Court further noted that the Convention protects the freedom of religious associations to exist and to provide a framework for the practice of their faith.

The Court held that the rejection of the applicant association’s application for registration as a religious association was not based on the applicant association’s religious beliefs, but rather on the grounds that the applicant association did not meet the statutory requirements for registration under the Act.

The Court further noted that the Act did not define the term “religious doctrine”, and that the Bulgarian authorities had not provided any explanation as to why the applicant association’s lack of a religious doctrine would prevent it from being registered as a religious association. 1990s. The country’s location, its membership of the European Union, its tourist industry and its relative prosperity have all contributed to its attractiveness to traffickers.
30. The problem is not a new one. The Commissioner has been informed that, as far back as the 1960s, there were reports of women being brought from Greece and Turkey to Cyprus to work in the sex industry. The problem has, however, assumed alarming proportions in recent years.
31. The scale of the problem is difficult to assess with any degree of accuracy. The authorities estimate that there are between 2,000 and 3,000 women in the country who have been trafficked for sexual exploitation. The NGOs working in the field suggest that the figure could be much higher.
32. The women come from a variety of countries. The largest number are from Bulgaria, Romania, Russia and Ukraine. The majority are believed to have been brought to Cyprus by traffickers, although some come voluntarily, lured by the promise of well-paid work.
33. The women are often subjected to appalling conditions. They are forced to work in brothels, nightclubs and bars. They are frequently subjected to violence and abuse, including rape and sexual assault. They are often deprived of their passports and are not allowed to leave their places of work. They are frequently threatened with violence and are often beaten if they refuse to comply with the demands of their employers. They are often subjected to threats of reprisals against their families if they try to escape.
34. The authorities have taken some steps to combat the problem. The police have set up a special unit to deal with trafficking cases. The Ministry of Labour has issued a circular to all employers reminding them of their obligations under the law. The authorities have also taken measures to strengthen the legal framework.
35. However, there are still serious shortcomings in the response to the problem. The police are under-resourced and lack the necessary expertise to deal effectively with trafficking cases. The legal framework is inadequate and does not provide sufficient protection for the victims. The authorities have not yet taken effective measures to provide adequate support for the victims, such as shelter, medical care and legal assistance.

The applicant also sought a declaration that the compulsory acquisition of his property was invalid for the reason that the Minister had not followed the procedure prescribed by the Compulsory Acquisition of Immovable Property Act.

B.  Relevant domestic law and practice

The following provisions of the Civil Code are relevant for the present case:

Article 1332
“(1) A person whose property has been taken for public needs, for the protection of public order or for the needs of a local authority, shall be entitled to compensation in accordance with the law.
(2) The taking of property for public needs shall be effected by a court order, or by a decision of the Government or a local authority.
(3) The taking of property for the protection of public order shall be effected by a court order.
(4) The taking of property for the needs of a local authority shall be effected by a decision of the local authority.
(5) A person whose property has been taken shall be entitled to claim its return if the taking was unlawful or if the public needs for which the property was taken have ceased to exist.
(6) A person whose property has been taken for public needs shall be entitled to claim its return if he has been paid compensation in accordance with the law.
(7) If a person has been paid compensation for property taken for public needs, the right to claim its return shall lapse after three years from the date of payment of the compensation.
(8) The taking of property for public needs shall not affect the right to claim compensation for the value of the property taken.
(9) If the taking of property for public needs has resulted in damage to the property, the person whose property has been taken shall be entitled to claim compensation for the damage.”

Article 1333
“(1) A person whose property has been taken for public needs shall be entitled to claim its return if the taking was unlawful or if the public needs for which the property was taken have ceased to exist.
(2) The right to claim the return of property taken for public needs shall lapse if the person concerned has not claimed its return within one year from the date of the taking.

The applicant company argued that the Market Court had made a mistake in law by applying the test of a 'substantial likelihood' of a cartel's existence instead of the test of a 'probability' of a cartel's existence. The applicant company submitted that the test of a 'probability' of a cartel's existence was more appropriate in cases where direct evidence was not available. The applicant company also argued that the Market Court had made a mistake in law by applying the test of a 'substantial likelihood' of a cartel's existence in respect of the local government and private sector contracts, while applying the test of a 'probability' of a cartel's existence in respect of the central government contracts. The applicant company submitted that the Market Court had made a mistake in fact by finding that the evidence was sufficient to prove the existence of a cartel in respect of the local government and private sector contracts, while finding that the evidence was insufficient in respect of the central government contracts. The applicant company also argued that the Market Court had made a mistake in fact by finding that the applicant company had engaged in bid rigging in respect of certain tenders, while finding that the applicant company had not engaged in bid rigging in respect of other tenders.

The Market Court rejected the applicant company's arguments. The Market Court held that the test of a 'probability' of a cartel's existence and the test of a 'substantial likelihood' of a cartel's existence were not mutually exclusive. The Market Court further held that the test of a 'probability' of a cartel's existence was not more appropriate in cases where direct evidence was not available, as the term 'probability' did not necessarily imply the absence

A.  Admissibility

1.  Compliance with the six-month rule

The Court notes that the applications were lodged on 12 October 1998, 23 October 1998 and 25 October 1998 respectively. The six-month rule was complied with.

2.  Admissibility of the complaints under Article 14 of the Convention

The Court notes that the applications were lodged with the European Commission of Human Rights on 12 October 1998, 23 October 1998 and 25 October 1998 respectively. The Commission declared the applications inadmissible on 26 October 1998, 28 October 1998 and 29 October 1998 respectively, as being out of time.

The Court reiterates that the six-month rule, which is a rule of prudence, does not apply to complaints under Article 14 of the Convention (see, among other authorities, the Vogt case, judgment of 26 September 1995, Reports of Judgments and Decisions 1995-IV, p. 1201, § 31).

The Court therefore concludes that the applications are admissible under Article 14 of the Convention.

B.  Merits

1.  Background

The Court notes that the special teams were established in 1996 and that their members were drawn from the DUR. The special teams were not subject to the same legal provisions as the DUR. They were not part of the Ministry of the Interior and Administration but were subordinated to the Office of the Prosecutor General. Their members were not entitled to the same social benefits as the DUR members.

Article 5

The applicants complain that they were detained in violation of Article 5 § 1 of the Convention. They argue that the detention was not based on a warrant or other lawful order and that it was arbitrary.

Article 5 § 1 of the Convention provides:

"1. Everyone has the right to liberty and security of person. No one shall be deprived of his liberty save in the following cases and in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law:
(a) the lawful detention of a person after conviction by a competent court;
(b) the lawful arrest or detention of a person for the execution of a sentence or detention order;
(c) the lawful detention of a person for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authorities on reasonable suspicion of having committed an offence or when it is reasonably considered necessary to prevent his committing an offence or fleeing after having done so;
(d) the detention of a minor by lawful order for the purpose of educational supervision or his lawful detention for the purpose of bringing him before the juvenile court.

The trial of Ronald Blistier, a militant of the Front National, who confessed to having committed one of these murders, took place in 1996.
The novel recounts the trial and the reactions of the various parties involved. The defence lawyer, Pierre Mine, is a Jew who has left the Communist Party to defend the rights of minorities, and he is deeply shocked by the racist and homophobic nature of the crime. He is also aware of the fact that his Jewishness and his homosexuality make him a target for the extreme right.
The prosecutor, who is a member of the Front National, is determined to prove that Blistier is not guilty and that the crime was committed by a group of North African immigrants. He uses every trick in the book to discredit the defence and to portray Blistier as a hero.
The jury, which is made up of ordinary citizens, is divided. Some of them are sympathetic to the defence, while others are convinced that Blistier is guilty. The novel describes in detail the arguments and counter-arguments that are presented during the trial, as well as the reactions of the various parties involved.
The novel also explores the backgrounds of the various characters and their motivations. Pierre Mine is a complex and fascinating character, who is deeply committed to the cause of justice and equality, but who is also haunted by his past. He is a Holocaust survivor, and he has seen first-hand the devastating effects of racism and hatred.
The novel also sheds light on the motivations of the extreme right. It shows how they use fear and hatred to mobilize their supporters and to justify their violent actions. It also shows how they exploit the fears and anxieties of ordinary people, who are worried about crime and insecurity, and how they use these fears to gain power and influence.
The novel is a powerful and thought-provoking exploration of the nature of hate and prejudice, and of the ways in which they can be challenged and overcome. It is a must-read for anyone who is interested in the issues of racism, homophobia, and the extreme right.
